### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Output: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many girls wore dresses of color?<n>Output: 8<n><n>Input:I want you to get a 15% and not a 4% if you're going lower on the curve.<n><n>Output:I want you to achieve an 15% and lower if you want to get in the curve.<n><n>### Instruction:In your own words please explain the above problems and make a function that solves them..<n><n>### Solution<n>Here is what I've done so far<n>- Brenda has 9 cards more:<n><n>`9 > Brenda`<n><n>- `9 > Brenda` <= 150<n><n>- Making Brenda as the base variable, `Brenda >= 9 == true and Brenda <= 150 == true`<n>- So 9 > Brenda  is true and 150 <= Brenda is true<n><n>- So brenda must have a value inbetween `9 and 150`<n><n>- So Brenda is an integer between 9 and 151<n><n>- 9 > Brenda and 9 <= Brenda<n><n>- Therefore I have a base variable Brenda that can have any integer between 9 and  150<n><n>For the other questions there isn't much that needs to be done. It would be pretty straightforward.<n><n>You can use the formula `Brenda = 9 + int(round((Brenda - 9)/150))` to achieve that result.<n><n>### Question 5<n>I've found a lot of possible errors in both of my loops. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Output: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Output: 6<n><n>Input:What is committing perjury likely to lead to? Choices:  A: shame B: arrest C: embarrassment D: go to jail E: tension<n>Output:		A<n>### Note:This problem has been provided by Code.org and the original problem can be found [here](https://www.code.org/study/coding-careers/what-to-expect/interview-questions/c-programming/37-if-else#multichoice-questions)<n>#### Solution<n>```cpp<n>#include <stdio.h><n>int main()<n>{<n>	int choice,ans1=0,ans2=0,answer=0,i=0,j=0;<n>	printf("Janet has 9 cards > Brenda. Mara > Brenda. How many cards do we have in all? \n");<n>	scanf("%i", &choice);<n>	if(choice==1)<n>		ans1=1;<n>	else if(choice==2)<n>		ans2=1;<n>	if(ans1 || ans2)<n>		answer=211;<n>	else<n>		answer = 0;<n>	printf("%i", answer);<n>	return 0;<n>}<n>```<n>

The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Output: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Output: 6<n><n>Input:If you were looking for a lemur where would you find it? Choices:  A: russia B: at home C: hole D: field E: heaven<n>Output:		C<n>Input: How many times greater is 35.6 than 5.25? Choices: 35.6 A: times B: 3 times C: 5 times D: 4 times E: 9 times<n>Output: A<n><h2>Tips for solving: </h2><n>Firstly, I used this https://math.liberty.edu/resources/worksheets-studyguide-help-tutorial/number-system/ as a guide for multiplication table. This will help us in determining the digits of the numbers, it will also enable us to answer the questions<n><h2>My approach : </h2><n>In most of the questions we first determined the digit of the numbers, we then used these steps:<n><ol><n><li>divide 9 -3 (in the number)</li><n><li>subtract (in the number) +3</li><n><ul><n></li><n></ul><n></ol><n>In this examples we subtracted (3+7)*9 which gave us a number of a different type(number of digits), so we added 1 to the number of digits, the final number of digits was 7.<n><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-146" src="{{site.url}}/wp-content/uploads/2017/09/Tips-1.png" alt="" width="263" height="613" srcset="{{site.url }}/wp-content/upload<n>

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Output: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Output: 6<n><n>Input:What type of home is most likely to have an attic filled with historical items? Choices:  A: top of home B: older houses C: victorian house D: own home E: material<n>Output:		 C<n><n>Input:How many pairs of sunglasses have you  bought  this year? Choices:  a: 3 b: 9 c: 12 d: 6 e: 18<n>Output:  B<n><n>Input:How  many times  have  you  cleaned  your  house  this month? Choices:  b: 30 c: 20 d: 17 e: 5<n>Output:  E<n><n>##<n><n>## Instruction:<n>Implement the above problem in Python.<n><n>## How?<n><n>Your program must work in this Python code:<n>```python<n>#!/usr/bin/env python<n><n>import sys<n>from collections import Counter<n><n>print(Counter(sys.argv[1:]).most_common(1)[0][0])<n>```<n>### Why?<n>It is a simple interview task. <n>### Example:<n><n>Input : Janet has 9 cars more than Brenda. Mare has twice as many cards than Janet. How many cars do they have in total as Mare has 40 cards?<n><n>The output is 211. <n><n>### Answer(s):<n><n>### Discussions:<n><n>I feel like I should get most of the instructions right but as I am new to Python and programming, I have some doubts.<n><n>### Other related links:<n><n>https://www.geeksforgeeks.org/python-counter-class/<n>https://www.w3schools.com/python/python_collections_counter.asp<n>https://www.programiz.com/python-programming/methods/counter/count<n><n><n>## Author : <n>Amit Kumar<n><n>##### Code License: MIT License<n>##### Author License: MIT License

If 75% of 60 people play football then how many football players were there in the first place?<n>Output: 125<n>### Instruction:Answer the question in C++.<n>### Instruction : Use following methods to answer question in C++<n>* getCard()<n>* minus()<n>* add()<n>## Instruction : use following data structure to answeer question in C++<n> * Hand(Card* cardPtr = nullptr)<n> *   {<n> *     return  *cardPtr;<n> *   }<n> * Hand::plus(const Hand& inOther)<n> * {<n> *   Card* cardPtr = new Card();<n> *   if (getCard() == 0)<n> *     {<n> *     return inOther.getCard();<n> *     }<n> *   if (inOther.getCard() == 1)<n> *     {   return inOther.getOtherCard();<n> *         }<n> *   else //inOther.getCard == 0<n> *     {   cardPtr->setCard(getCard()-1);<n> *       return inOther.getOthetCard();<n> *     inOther.getOotherCard().<n> *     }<n><n> * Hand::minus(const Hand& inCard)<n> * {<n>     Card* cardPtr =  new Card();<n>     return  inCard.getCard() - 1;<n>    }<n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Output: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Output: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Output: 6<n><n>Input:The person knew the police were after him, so what did he do? Choices:  A: the sun B: catch cold C: prepare to go D: feel humiliated E: hunt for food<n>Output:		Hunt For Food<n><n><n>### Solution:<n>```java<n>class Solution {<n>  public int solveDinerProblem(int n) {<n>    int total=0;<n>    for(int i=1,num;i<=n;i++){<n>    	num=(i%2)+1;<n>    	total+=(i/2)*2;<n>    	}<n>    return(total);<n>    }<n>  }<n>```

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Output: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Output: 6<n><n>Input:Someone who is awake is likely to know what's going on because they are this? Choices:  A: alert B: deep sleep C: drink coffee D: open eyes E: conscious<n>Output:		<n><n><n>#### Answer:<n><n>### #1.<n><n>Janet has 9 cards<n>Mara has twice as many cards<n>The total number of cards is 211<n>### #2.<n><n>Pete walked 5 blocks<n>The number of blocks he went is 50<n><n> <n>### #3.<n><n>Number of green chair is 3 times as many than the number of blue chair (given green chair is 3 more than the blue chair)<n>The number of white chair is 13 less than the green chair + blue chair (given blue chair is 3 more and green chair is 3 less)<n>The number of green chair + blue chair is 2<n>Which is given as: <n>3* (the number of blue chair) + 1 - (the number of white chair)<n><n>The number of white chairs is:<n>13 - 2 = 11<n>The number of green + blue chair is: 2<n>The number of white color chair is: 11<n>The sum of them all to equal 21<n>The number of chair must divide by 21 ( to get the whole number)<n>Hence: the number of chair is: 21/21 = 1<n><n>### #4.<n><n>Genevieve had 6<n><n>**Hint:**<n><n>the number of cup Genevieve took is 3. the total number of cup in all = 43<n>so, the remainder after dividing 43 by 3 is 6. <n><n>### #5<n>The options represent the state of being:<n>1: alert<n>2: deep sleep<n>3: drink coffee<n>4: open eyes<n>5: conscious<n>

The variable name in this case is total.<n>Input:total = 9<n><n>The expression in the left hand side is the same as the expression in the right hand side which is equal to the value 9. Hence the output of this program is 9.<n><n>Input:total = total+5<n><n>The expression in left hand side is the value of 9 which is equal to the expression on the right hand side. The new value is 14.<n><n>Input:num = num+num<n><n>There is an error in this program. The expression in left hand side and expression on right hand side are same and the new value is 13.<n><n>

Please do not copy paste the answer.<n><n>The first line of input contains an integer 'T'. This is the number of tests and all the integers are separated by a space.<n>The following line of input contains 'K' numbers. If we divide all those integers by 2 then the last integer is the remainder. The rest of the integers are the total number of integers in the number.<n>The number of tests which were input will generate K numbers. Each test would have the following K lines<n>For every test there are K different numbers.<n>The answer is the sum of all the remaining numbers until the final remainder.<n>The answer for the last input should be same as the input if the original number is divided by 2.<n>You can go to this link to check the input test:https://www.hackerrank.com/challenge/number-theory/submissions/320986854<n>

Please see the following example.<n><n>Input: A farmer owned 57 chickens. Then he decided to halve the number of chickens he owned with each subsequent division. What is the least number of chickens that the farmer will have in the end?<n>Output: 13<n><br/><br/><n>Step 1: Choose the best model for the problem from the choices listed. Note that if there are no multiple choice selections the model is the correct model.<n><n>![](/images/6.PNG)<n><br/><hr /><n>Step 2: Create and simplify all possible numbers that can be made using the operators provided.<n><n>![](/img/6.PNG){:.box}<n><br/><sup>The model can be used as an indicator for step 2.</sup><n><br/><!-- <br/> --><n><n>Step 3: Perform operations as indicated by arrows.<n><n><div class="text-center"> <img style="width: 35rem;" src="images/6.Png" class="z-6"> </div><n><n>Step 4: Write an expression and perform operation to get your answer.<n><n>\[57\div 2\div 2\times 1 = 13\]<n>

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Output: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. Choices:  A: nature B: toilet C: computer science D: computer store E: human body<n>Output:		E<n><n>### Solution:First of all I made the formula that the value of the question is 211.Here are the formula used in calculating this value.<n>> Total - (Number of brenda - Number of Janet)<n><n>Here are the formula used for computing the answer:<n><n>>Total Number of cards Brenda and janet.<n>>Subtract total number of cards from total number of cards janet and brenda have.<n><n><n>### Example:<n>Example 1)Pete walked 10 blocks from his house to station,from station he boarded bus went 15 blocks to post office and returned home,find block pete walked in total.<n>Example 2)Total no of Chairs in a classroom(36 chairs and 16 chairs are blue,6 chairs are green and 13 chairs are white)how many chairs are in a classroom.<n>Example 3)In canteen 15 pints of coffee were served each into a different container there were a total of 32 pints how much pints did Genevieve drank?<n>Soln : In this first 6 is the answer.For remaining question I followed the rule that:<n>>Total = Number of chair Green+Blue+White<n><n>**Answer**:<n>Input: Janet Has 9 cards more than brenda. <n><n>If the value of the question was to be calculated in the following manner(according to my own formula).<n>>>>Total - (Number of brendra - Number of janet)<n><n>Then the value of question will be 211.<n><n>### Comments<n>1)I have not calculated according to this formula.<n>2)Since the question did not provided the method used in calculations, so it will be considered as unsolvable.<n>3)This question doesnot provide the information, so the answer is 67.<n>4)Since it is provided that there were 10 blue chair,10 blue chair and 4 green chair.It is possible that green chair is 3 times greater than the value of the blue chair.Therefore all the information provided, I was not able to solve the question.<n>5)In canteen 32 pints of coffee were there,and each was into a different container so,how many pints did Genevive's drink

How much water will there be in 2 bowls?<n>Output: 7 inches<n><n>Input: There are 41 cars in the park. 40% are small cars. 31 are large cars. There are also 22 motorcycles. What is the largest percentage of cars that are not small cars?<n>Output: 83%<n><n>Input: Two girls were eating jelly donuts. They each ate half of their jelly donuts. A jelly donut is 60% of a cookie. How many cookies were in total?<n>Output : 3<n><n><n>### Answer all five questions.<n>### Answer only question number 6.

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Output: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Output: 6<n><n>Input:What is someone watching a person who is playing guitar doing? Choices:  A: auditioning B: hear sounds C: listening to music D: making music E: arthritis<n>Output:		A is the only answer.<n><n>Input : What comes next in the following sequence?  ___ 42 6 426 79 ___ 4<n>Output :79<n><n>Input : Which of these is not a true statement about angles? Choices :  A: The four angles in a square have four different sizes. B: Each angle is an angle. C: There are eight interior angles in a rectangle. D: The three angles in a triangle sum to 180°.<n>Output : B is not a true statement<n><n>Input:In a classroom with 14 students, 21 desks, 10 chairs and 16 pencils, how many pencils do only the girls in the classroom have?<n>Output:15<n><n>Input:Three girls had a total of 313 pencils combined. Each girl was given the same number of pencils. What is missing from the equation?<n>Output: 1<n><n>Input:What number comes next in the following arithmetic sequence?  , 44,, 60,, 71<n>Output : 79<n><n>Input: Find the value of 1 × 2 × 3 × 4 × 5 × 6 × 7 × 8.<n>Output: 1234567890<n><n>Solution:<n>First Case:<n>input: Janet has 14 cards more than Brenda, Mara has twice as<n>many cards as Janet.<n>output: 211, Because of 14 cards, Brenda has the same number of<n>cards as Janet.<n>Next Brenda has 3 times as many cards than Marina<n>and the same number as Janet.<n>Janet's cards: 14+2 times Brenda cards + Marina card =<n>Brenda + 2*Marina cards + Janet's cards = 211<n>Then Brenda + Marina cards = 210<n>Next Brenda has twice the cards than Marina and the<n>same number of cards as Janet. then Marina =2 * Janet =<n>4<n>Next Brenda cards + Marina cards = 18x8 = 144<n>Next Brenda + Marina cards + Janet cards = 183<n>Then Marina + Janet cards =1 + 8

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Output: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Output: 6<n><n>Input:What is illegal to do when you play cards at a casino? Choices:  A: remember B: help C: count D: winning E: dealing<n>Output:		c<n><n>Input: The blue and purple flowers were planted in the spring. The blue and green flowers were planted in summer. Choices: a,b,c<n>Output: a<n><n>Input:The sum of a number and 5 is 11. The reciprocal of the number is 3/2. What is the number? Choices:a. 5 b. 3 c. 7 d. 6<n>Output:a<n><n>Input: The sum of a number and -5 is -11. The reciprocant of the number is 5/3. What is the number. Choices:a.18 b. 9 c.8 d. -6<n>Output:9<n><n>Input: If the value of a - b is 19, the value of a is 8. The value of b is 25. What is the value of b?Choices:a. 10 b. 20 c. 38 d. 42<n>Output: a<n>Input: 13/22. 15/18. 19/9/6/3 = 3/22. What is the value of 13/20? Choices:a.32/19 b.30/9 c.43/10 d.32/30<n>Output: b<n><n>Input: Find the median of 7, 2, 9, 4, 12, 8, 23, 11, and 17. Choices: a. 9 b.9.5 c.22 d.23<n>Output:a<n>Input: a. A line is not tangent to the circle described by the equation (x - 5)2 + (y - 1)2 - 4 = 0 b. The circumference of a circle and side of right triangle<n>Output: ab<n>Input: 9 less than the product of 8 and x: 9, x, a. 1/2, b. 1/32<n>Output: a
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Output: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Output: 6<n><n>Input:At a state fair judging pigs requires careful what? Choices:  A: verdict B: judging C: responsibility D: evaluating E: prejudice<n>Output:		B: judging<n><n>Input: After 3 days, he made 536 trips to the grocery store. How many trips per day did he have?<n>Output: 179<n><n>### Code<n><n>```python<n>import math<n># function to find cards<n>def print_difference(l1, l2):<n> print("Janet has "+ str(l1-l2) +" more cards than Brenda. Maras have twice as many cards as janet.")<n> # calculate cards<n> Janet=40 <n> Brenda=5  <n> cards= 40+40*2 - 150  <n><n> # function to solve problems<n> def print_sum(l1, l3, l4):<n>  if l1==l2 or l3==l4:<n>   print('The total number of blocks =',l1+(l2-l1) +l3-(l4-l3)) #sum<n><n>print("Input: Input number of blocks (l1) and the total of l1-(l2-l1)+l3-(l4.l3)) to calculate total in all blocks.")<n>while True:<n>   line=eval(input('Enter blocks: '))<n>   if line==0:# quit loop when user inputs zero<n>    break<n>   if line==20:<n>    break<n>   else:<n>    print(line) #prints the line entered by user<n><n>   print_sum = l1, l4, l3<n>   break<n>```<n><n>

Choices:  A: problems B: not noticeable C: deflation D: economic instability E: eat cake<n>Output:		D<n>```<n><n>## Challenge<n><n>Write code for the following function.<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice questions.<n><n>Input: 110 degrees<n>Output: 100 degrees<n>```<n><n>### Part 1<n><n>Write function to solve the problem<n><n>```<n>var convert = function(str){<n>    var newStr = str.toString().toLowerCase().replace(/\d/g, "");<n>    var newStr_array = newStr.split(" ");<n>    var str_array = [];<n>    for (let i = 0; i < newStr_array.length; i++){<n>        str_array.push(newStr_array[i]);<n>    }<n>    str_array = str_array.join("")<n>    return str_array}<n>```<n><n>## Part 2<n><n>Write function to do the reverse of above conversion<n><n>```<n>var reverse = function(str){return newStr.toLowerCase().replace(" ","$").replace(/[^0-9\d]/g, ""));}<n>```

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Output: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Output: 6<n><n>Input:Sam left his muddy shoes in the entryway.  Where might he be? Choices:  A: department store B: school C: garden D: office building E: house<n>Output:		B<n><n>Comment: Hey, welcome to Code Review! While it's nice that you came here with questions, posting uncommented code is against our rules to prevent code dumping. Consider posting one question with a self-contained example, and then add your second question. You can always add more questions after receiving feedback on your first one.<n><n>Answer: The only reason for a loop is if there are more questions than the number you want to handle. Otherwise, just print what you're asked to output.<n><n>A classroom has two ways to sit -- a table or a chair. So subtract 1 from the number of chairs. (A chair and a table count as two seats. A teacher doesn't have a seat, but we do have to count the teacher's desk. The teacher counts as \em{part} of the desk.)<n><n>In your example, Pete started at the 7th street crossing. Going by bus, he stopped first at the first stop, reached the next stop on the sixth block, and then continued on.<n><n>So how many blocks did he traverse? Two blocks per bus stop, plus one for every 5 blocks before the first stop.<n><n>What's with your numbers? Firstly, don't mix up kilograms and grams. A kg is 1000 gram, so a kilo is a gram more (or 1000 grams) than what you report. Secondly, you use metric and imperial in the same example and so don't distinguish between "4.5" and "5".<n><n>There seem to be three types of question here:<n>\begin{itemize}<n>\item A person goes some way and is then given money to make the journey to somewhere else.<n>\item A person collects cards, and the question is about a collection of cards<n>\item A classroom has chairs.<n>\end{itemize}<n><n>For the first of these, add up the distance.<n><n>For the second, count how many chairs there are to start with. Subtract the number that were returned by question 1.<n><n>For the third, first add 1. Then look for any "seats" (a chair or a table) whose count is more than 1. When there are no "multiples" remaining to "reduce" you know that you've reached the end

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Output: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Output: 6<n><n>Input:What will all the differences equal? Choices:  A: sum B: likeness C: alike D: sameness E: similarity<n>Output:		C<n><n>#### Solution<n><n>For part 1,<n><n>We can use a method similar to the one used in the previous question. If the total is 211, then that means Janet's cards are 211-Brenda's cards, which is the same thing as saying that Brenda's cards are 9.<n><n>We can then look at this:<n><n>Mara has 2x$Janet$, which means we can divide the total by 2, and this gives us 105.5. So, Mara's cards are roughly $(105.5+Brenda's cards)$/2, which means Brenda's cards were $($(105.5-Mara's cards)-50)/2$<n><n>Since $(105.3+Brenda's card - 50)/2$ is a number between 0 and 99, and we know that $(105.4+Brenda's Card - 50)$ is also, this tells us that $(Brenda's Card)$ is $50 - 4(Brenda's Card) $<n><n>Since Brenda's Card is unknown, then $Brenda's Card = 50 - 4 * unknown $<n><n>Since $(Brenda's card = 50 -4*unknown)$, if we assume Brenda's card is 30, then for $unknown$ it breaks down as follows<n><n>$50 - 4*30 = 20 = $unknown<n><n>Because this simplifies to $(Brenda's cards = 30 - unknown)$<n><n>$30 - 35 = (-5)$<n><n>which is negative<n><n>Brenda's card is unknown. So, there are 143 cards.<n><n>For part 2<n><n>We can split the total into 4.5 gallon chunks, so the answer is between 4 and 5. So, Pete drank 5 gallons.<n>For part 3<n><n>We can use this method again. We know that for every 3 blue chairs, there are 1 green chair. We also know that there are 2 more white chairs than blue chairs, meaning that no other color is equal to 62 chairs<n><n>So that way,

How many girls had the classroom?<n>Output 10<n><n><n>     ***Problem statement:***<n>     Find the number of boys in the classroom.<n>     ***Expected Output:***<n>     9<n><n>     **Code:**<n>     def Solution(input):<n>       n = int(input)<n>       male = 0<n>       female = 0<n>       # Sum total of boys and girls<n>       sum = 0<n>       for num in range(n):<n>         if num % 2 == 0:<n>           sum += 1<n>         else:<n>           print(sum)<n>        return sum<n><n><n>     ***Note:*** You may use any standard data structures and classes that are provided by your language.<n><n>     ***Problem Statement: (What are you expected to do?)***<n>     Find out the number of boys.<n><n>'''<n><n># Driver Code<n><n>def main():<n>    # TEST CODEC HE<n><n>if __name__ == '__main__':<n>    main()<n><n># Test Code<n><n>import pytest<n><n><n>class TestCode(object):<n>    def test_T1(self):<n>        assert Solution(10) == 9<n><n>    def test_E1(self):<n><n>        for test in

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Output: 6<n><n>Input:The explorers found a central passage, much to their delight it led straight to the ancient buried what? Choices:  A: public building B: tomb C: arena D: large building E: treasure<n>Output:		B<n><n><n>### Instruction:Use the `main function` to create the program.<n>```c<n>#include <stdio.h><n>#include <stdlib.h><n><n>  // **** Define variables ****<n>int main()<n>{<n>    char input; // define the variable for the user input<n>    char output; // declare the variable for the user output<n>    long num1;<n>    long num2;<n>    long num3;<n>    long sum;<n>    long diff;<n>    int counter;<n>    counter = 0;<n>    while (counter < 5) // define a counter variable, and loop through it 5 times<n>    {<n>        printf("1. How many cards do you have?\n");<n>        printf("2. How many blocks do you walk?\n");<n>	printf("3. How many Chairs do you have?\t");<n>	printf("4. How much coffee do you drink?\n");<n>       printf("5. How many people do you see?\t");<n>        scanf("%c", &input);<n>        if (input == '1')<n>        {<n>            printf("\t\t\t\tEnter your number: ");<n>            scanf("%ld", &num1);<n>            printf("\tYour total number of cards are %ld\t", num1);<n>        }       <n>        else if (input == '2')<n>        {<n>        	printf("\t\t\n\t\t\nEnter the first number you walk: \n");<n>        	scanf("%ld", &sum);<n>        	printf("\nEnter the second number you walk: \t");<n>        	scanfi("%ld", &diff);<n>        	sum = sum + diff;<n>        	printf("Your total is %ld blocks\n\t", sum);<n>        }<n>        else if ( input == '3' )<n>        {<n>        <n>		int p = 0;<n><n>        	for(;p < 4; p++ )<n>        	{<n><n>                printf("\nWhat color are the chairs: ");<n>                scanf("%c",&counter);<n>                if (counter== 'A')<n>                {<n>                	printf("Choose B or G: ");<n>                	scanf("%c",&input);<n>                
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. That way he will be able to rent 8 cars.<n><n>Input:350 days passes each year. 88% as many days pass in a minute as a year as pass in a month and 14 days passes in a minute. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. Choices:  A: plain B: cold C: dull D: bad E: wet<n>Output:		plain Answer <n><n>#!/bin/bash <n>iValueA=`echo $1 | awk '{print $1}'`<n>iNumA=`echo $1|awk '{print $2}'` <n>iValueA++<n>iValueA=iValueA%iNumA<n>echo $iValueA<n><n>iValueB=`echo $2 | awk '{print $2}' | awk '{print $3}'`<n>iNumB=`echo $1 |awk '{print $3}' | awk '{print  $2}'`  #same as<n>echo $iValueB $iNumB <n>iValueB=iValueB%iNumB<n>echo $iValueC<n>echo $iValueD<n>echo $iValueE<n>echo $iValueF<n>

The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Output: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Output: 6<n><n>Input:When a snake prefers warm, sunny weather, where would it likely want to live? Of these, 14 are red, 11 are white, and 8 are blue. How much is each color worth?<n>Output:  Red-2 Red+White-2 Red-Blue-1 Blue+White-1<n><n>### Instructions: Find the missing letter by making changes to one letter only. A word is defined to be a sentence. <n><n><n>Input: "We have to find a better way of doing things."<n>Output: C, F<n><n>### Your Code<n>```<n>input = input.split(",")<n>input = [a for a in input if a.replace("","")!= ""]<n>if len(input) == 1 and inputs!= inputs in input[0] == '':<n>    print(f'No input')<n>    return<n><n>diffrence = input[1] - input[0]<n>if diffrence in diffrence:<n><n>    count = 0<n>    for diffrence_str in diffrence: <n>        count += 1<n>        if diffrence_str not in count:<n>            count = 0<n><n>    print(count)<n>else:<n>    print(f"'{input[0]}' has not occurred")<n>```<n>

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. Use it to test and create a new piece of programming puzzle.<n>### Program Input:<n>P1<n><n>P2<n><n>P3<n><n>P4<n><n>### The program has to follow a set of steps<n><n>1) Read the program and input.<n><n>2) Output the correct answer.<n><n>3) Clear the memory and repeat steps 1 and 2 until all data have been passed through the program.<n><n>### The Program <n><n>Puzzle(input,answer){<n>	if (input[0]!=x or answer==41 and answer.y!=3){<n>		x = answer.x<n>		answer.y = 1<n>	}else if (input[0] == x){<n>		if (x==x){<n>			answer.x = x<n>			answer = x<n>		}else if (x==x){ <n>			x= answer-x<n>			x.y += 1<n>		}<n>	}else{<n>		x.y > 1<n>	}<n>}<n>

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. Choices:  A: new york B: coastal cities C: city D: coastal cities E: boston<n>Output:		B<n><n>### Explanation:<n><n>It looks like it takes many hours. But if we do this like this:<n><n>1. 50+9->70<n><n>2.   //Maras number+Janets number -> 40<n><n>3.  Pete+Janets number: ((40)+40) ->100 <n><n>4.  ((15/150-40)/2) = 1/7 ->15 and the answer = 211<n>

Choices:  A: insect repellent B: heart attacks C: improved health D: shin splints E: being tired<n>Output:		C<n><n>- A and B are not good choices<n>- C is one way to be healthier and have a better life<n>- D is one way to get heart attacks and shin splints<n>- E is always the result of not jogging enough<n><n>---<n>[back to index](/README.md)

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Output: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Output: 6<n><n>Input:How might a person address someone who is leaving? Choices:  A: further cause B: wave goodbye C: attempt suicide D: insulting them E: thank god<n>Output:		A<n>### Solution:<n>This problem is about the multiplication of the digits in one number with the digits in another. <n>I decided to try out both approaches (using recursion and iteration), then analyzed which one to choose. <n><n>Using recursion, I would write in code<n>```<n>int Solution::solution(vector<int>& nums) {<n><n>    if (nums.size() == 1) return nums[0];<n>    int res = Solution().solution(nums.erase(nums.begin(),nums.begin()+nums.size()/2));<n>    res *= Solution().solution(vector< int >(nums.erse(nums.begin() + nums.size() / 2, nums.end()));<n><n>    return res;<n>}<n>```<n><n>As the number of digits is known in advance at all times, recursion should be the best option. <n><n>However, I believe that using iteration is more readable and intuitive, so I decided to use it, and to check the computational time. <n><n>My chosen solution was <n><n>```<n>int Solution {<n>        public:<n>        int solution(vector<int> const& nums){<n>            int sum = pow(nums.size(), 2);<n>            int cnt = 1;<n>            for (int i = 1; i < nums.size(); i++) {<n>                for (int j = i + 1; j < nums.size() ; j++) {<n>                    //cout << i << "," << j << "," << sum << endl;<n>                    int productTemp = nums[i] * nums[j];<n>                    sum += pow(productTemp, 2);<n>                    sum += cnt;<n>                    cnt += 2;<n>                }<n>            }<n>            //cout << nums.size() << " " << nums[nums.size() - 1] << endl;<n>            int final = 0;<n>            int numDiv = nums.size();<n>            <n>            for (int j = 0; j < (int)sizeof(nums)/sizeof(nums[0]); j++) {<n>                int num = nums[j]; //final / numDiv;<n>                final = final % num;<n>

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Output: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Output: 6<n><n>Input:When would you be able to see your reflection in a piece of wood? Choices:  A: burned B: polished C: carved D: composted E: nailed<n>Output:		A<n><n>### Solution:<n>```<n>from utils.const import MAX_INT, min_value, max_value<n><n><n>def solve_3(n, k):<n>    if n == 0:<n>        return 0<n>    return solve_3(n // 2, k) + min(k, n)<n><n><n>def solve(n, k):  # n, A(n), B(n), C(n), D(n), E(n)<n>    if n == min_value:<n>        return max_value<n>    return max(<n>        max(solve(n // 2 - 1, n // 2, k=1) + n * (n // 2 - k), max_value),<n>        solve(n // 2 + 1, n //2, k=1),<n>    )<n><n><n><n>def main():<n>    n, k = parseInt(input()).value<n>    ans = solve(n, k)<n>    print(ans)<n><n><n>if __name__ == "__main__":<n>    main()<n>```

The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Output: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Output: 6<n><n>Input:A night owl is what you'd head at sunset and you'd hear a what at sunrise? Choices:  A: morning person B: early bird C: lark D: early riser E: rooster<n>Output:		D<n><n>input: 2.25 x 2.25 + 13.75 + 3.5 = _______.<n>    answer = 20.5 + 3.1750<n><n><n>```python<n>def get_chars(s):<n>    chars = set()<n>    for c in s:<n>        chars.add(c)<n>    return chars<n>```<n><n>def sum(str_in):<n><n>    s = get_char(str_in)<n><n>    total = 0<n><n>    for i in range(len(s)):<n>        total += s<n>        if i == len(s):<n>            total += s[0]<n><n>    return total<n><n>def get_char(str):<n>    s = list(str)<n>    return ''.join(s)<n><n>def get_length(val):<n>    l = ""<n>    for i in val:<n>        l += i<n><n>    return l<n><n>def get_multiply(s, l):<n>    for i in l:<n>        s += i<n><n>def f_sum(val):<n>    sum = val<n>    f_length(sum)<n>    f_multiply(sum, val)<n>```<n><n>### The following are input/output pairs for the function f_sum from the preceding functions.<n><n>Input: f_length("aaac" * 4) and f_multiply("aaac" *4,"aaac" *2)<n><n>Output:<n><n>```python<n>aaacaaaacaaaaaaaa<n>```<n><n><n>### The two input files readings.txt and readings2.txt have been provided for an easy implementation.<n><n>```python<n>#Reading1<n>with open('readings.txt', 'r') as fh:<n>    for line in fh:<n>        answer = int(line)<n>```<n><n>```python<n>fh1 = open('readings.csv','r')<n>        for line in fh1:<n>            answer = int(line.strip('\n'))<n>        print(answer)<n>fh1.close()<n>```<n><n>```<n>6096<n>123<n>5870<n>1443<n>432<n>4545<n>```<n><n>```java<n>public class First

A fraction is either a numerator divided by a denominator. There are three types of a fraction, which are fraction, mixed fraction, and improper fraction. The number part in a fraction 45/88 is the numerator. This fraction means 45. Denominator is 88. It means the number after the fraction. The fraction 45/A means the numerator is fortyfive and the denominator is eighty-eight. Fractions represent division. You usually use fractions to see how many parts there are. You use fractions to help you find fractions of any number. For example, if you split something into two parts, each part is one-half. When you split something into 3 parts, each part is 1/3.<n><n>Output: 1<n><n>Input: We used the following instructions to produce a 27 by 12 rectangle. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Output: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Output: 6<n><n>Input:What happens to the conscience of someone who has been caught committing a murder? Choices:  A: jail time B: fear C: going to prison D: nothing E: feeling of guilt<n>Output:		<n><n>#### Solution<n>```python<n>import math<n><n>def main():<n>    <n>    # Janet has 9 less cards than Brenda<n>    cardOne = int(input("How many cards does Janet have? "))- int(input("Howmany cards does brenda have?"))<n>    cardTwo = cardOne//2<n>    <n>    # cards total<n>    # cards total1 = cardOne +cardtwo<n>    # cards total2 = 490<n>    # cards total = cards total1 - cards total2<n>    cards_Total = cardOne - cardTwo - cardOne<n>    <n>    print(cards_Total)<n><n>    # mara has 150 cards<n>    mara_cards= int(input("How much cards does mara have in all? "))<n>    # we know<n>    cards_Total+ mara_cards<n>    # and<n>    <n>    # 150 -40 = 110<n>    #110/2 = 55<n><n>    print(cards)<n><n>main()<n><n>```<n><n>#### Explanation: It's just a simple problem.<n>We are given three pieces of information. First, janet has 9 more cards than brenda. Second, Mara's cards total<n>is 40 less than 159. Third, Mara's total cards are twice Janet. This gives us the following relationship.<n><p align="center"><n>   <img src="https://www.educoder.io/problem/python/cards-problem.png" width =100% height="Auto" /><n></p><n><n>#### Question:<n>```python<n><n>```<n>- (Q1) What is the total distance that Pete has traveled?<n><n>### Answer:<n>```python<n>import data<n><n>def main(): <n>    <n>    # blocks walked<n>    blocks = int(input("What blocks did Pete walk from his house to the post office? "))<n><n>    PostOffice_distance = blocks + data.number_of_Block_in_houston<n><n>    # distance walked<n>    distanceWalked = PostOffice_Distance + data.number_Of_block_in_Houston<n>    <n>    print('the distance Pete walked was'+ str(distanceWalk

How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Output: 6<n><n>Input:What cuisine is joked about eating small dogs? ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Output: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Output: 6<n><n>Input:The master control for the Tardis is where in the main room? Choices:  A: nuclear power plant B: center C: basement D: main office E: bowel of the ship<n>Output:		E<n><n>Instructions:<n><n>Write a program, Counter, that is executed via command-line and takes in positive integer input from the command-line arguments; count the number of words it receives;<n><n><n>#### Include in your program:<n><n>- A main function with the appropriate call to system.exit(0) on the main function’s last line<n>- A count function to be called from the main function that will count the number of arguments following the command-line call to the counting program<n>- A function header as appropriate for each subroutines/functions in your program, such as function declaration, parameter declaration;<n><n>The function header for count() should include an integer parameter followed by a colon and followed by two curly braces containing the body of the function. The body should contain the following code: <n>System.exit(argc>count(i));<n><n>- A call to count to run the code in the count function in the call to count function to pass in the count variable (in this case, argc)<n>- At minimum, one static variable<n>- A static main function and one static count function; do not put the count and main functions in a class. Do not use the var or other similar built-in variable;<n><n>In your program, Counter:<n><n>* count() takes in a single integer argument with number of words following the keyword count(), followed by a colon, and then followed by braces containing the function body with the function returning a value of the number of words to a calling function;<n><n>* Count() function body is the following System.exit(argc>>count(i));<n>* count() returns the integer value of the number of arguments following its call in the main function<n>* If the calling function passes in too many arguments, it should print a message;<n>* If the number of arguments after calling count(i) = 0, the function should return an error message;<n><n>The static count function and static main function should print what we pass and the number of arguments they receive.<n><n>For example, the main function might print the following, "The number of words you passed count is: "argc" followed by a newline and a space, followed by the following string, "[count] received number of arguments: " + count(i), followed by a newline, followed by the string, "total arguments: " + argc, followed by a newline

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Output: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Output: 6<n><n>Input:If I have a vintage, decorative light source in my possession, what is it likely to be? Choices:  A: sun B: sky C: candle D: house E: lamp<n>Output:		A: sun<n><n>Input: A: How many of the following sets of numbers contain a pair of consecutive odd integers? 1, 2, 13 2, 4, 6, 8 … 31, 32 … 100?<n>Output: C:<n>A set of numbers can only contain even or odd numbers. The first number can’t be even, because of no consecutive integers, so the only possibility is 31, 12, 109 which contains consecutive odd integers. Then the second number will always be odd, even if it’s between 21 and 99. Then we can conclude that the answer is C, where consecutive odd integers do not appear.<n><n>**Explanation**<n><n>If it is consecutive odd integers, the first and second numbers will make up the integers, while other numbers can then be divided between two groups: odd and even. Because odd number can’t contain even number, the total number of odd groups is 2 less than the one of even number.<n><n>Input: A 16-foot ladder leans against the side of a building. When the foot of the ladder is 9 feet from a window, the top of the ladder leans 9 feet away from the building. How high is the building?  <n>Output: Answer D<n><n>**Explanations**<n>Step1: Let us define the building as A, and its foot as F.<n><n>step2: A is 16 feet tall, so F is 7 feet tall.<n><n>step3: The angle between AF is 9, and the angle between AA’ is 90.<n>Solving the equations:<n>7/16 = 9/90 => 7 * cos(90degree) = 9 * cos(9degree) => sec(9degree) = 7/9<n>Therefore the building is 9 feet tall.<n><n>Input: 3+8 =?<n>Output: C<n>**Instruction***<n><n>Solution : **Ans 9**<n>So 12+8 = 20, 20+8 = 28, 28+8 = 36, 36+8 = 44, 44+8 = 52, 52+8 = 60

How many miles do the houses travel to the post office?<n>Output: 190<n><n>Explanation<n><n>The input above gives 2 different distances<n>342 houses 174 miles<n>342 houses = 174 houses plus the post office. So 174 + post office.<n>Also the only country given is the United States. If it was any other country you would subtract the distance by the distance to the post office which would be 342 - 174.<n><n>

For example, the answer to question number 5 is 34<n><n># Instrucions for part (c):<n><n>The questions will be multiple choice questions. The question will give two equations of two different numbers x and y in which only one of them can be negative. You need to tell me<n>which one is negative.<n># Instructions For Part (d):<n><n>The question will ask about two different equations.  Answer the true or false question at<n>the end of those two equations.  You need to tell me whether that equation is true or false<n><n># Instrucitons for part (e)<n>Input:  Toni, who started out as a baker and then became an accountant, retired from her accounting job after 30 years.  Her<n>accounting career consisted of 25 workdays on her salary in 1999, 32<n>workdays on her salary paid to her employer, and 68 workdays with no pay<n>at all.  During her last year, she was paid $62,000 for the 25 workdays. Choices:  A: wrong B: death of C: bad D: negative E: evil<n>Output:		 D: evil <n><n><n>#### Answer:<n><n>#include<iostream><n>#include<cstring><n>using namespace std;<n>int main()<n>{<n>    int arr4[9];<n>    int total1=0, total2=0, index2, currentIndex;<n>    cout<<"enter first array"<<endl;<n>    for(int i = 0; i < 9; i++)<n>    {<n>        cin>>arr4[i];<n>    }<n>    cout<<" Enter second array \n"<<endl;<n><n>    for(int j = 0; j < 9; j++)<n>    {<n>    <n>        cin>>arr5[j];<n>    }<n>     if(arr4[0]>arr4[1]){<n>            cout<<"" <<"index 0 "<< arr1[0];  <n>             } <n>                else if  (arr4[0]<arr4[1])  {cout <<"1 "<< arr1[index2-1]; }<n>                else{  <n>                cout<<"" <<"Enter the first array"<<endl<<"Enter the second array \n" <<endl;<n>                for(int n = 0; n<9; n++)<n>                {<n>                    cin>>arr4[n];<n>                }<n>                for(int l =0; l<9; l++)<n>                {<n><n>                    cout<<arr4[0]<<" ";<n>                    index2++ ;// increment the value of index2 by index2<n>        }total1=total1+index2;<n>        }<n><n>    }<n>if(arr4[4]> arr4[5]){<n>    for(int c = 0; c < 10; c++)<n>    {<n>         cout<<arr4[c];<n>           currentIndex++;<n>        }total2=currentIndex+total1;<n>}<n>   else if (arr4[4]< arr4[5])<n>    {  <n>    for(int y = 0; y <  10; y++)<n>    {<n><n>        cout<<arr4[y];<n>         currentIndex++;<n> <n><n>}total2=currentIndex +total1;<n>else<n>    { cout<<""<<" Enter the first array"<<" "<<

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Output: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. Choices:  A: assisted living facility B: old people's home C: high school or college D: republican party E: organization<n>Output:		c<n><n>## Instruction<n><n>We have to get the answer with these steps:<n><n>1.  Convert the integer to mixed fraction.<n>2. Divide the integer.<n>3. If the remain is >= 1 and <= 5, just take this remain as an answer.<n>4. Otherwise, subtract the remain from the divide and then proceed to Step3.<n>

Choices:  A: injury B: beauty C: late D: mistakes E: annoyed<n>Output:		B<n><n>## Instruction:Complete the function so that it returns the indicated output.<n><n>```<n>def findNthDigit(n)<n> n.to_s.rjust(n) # rjust(x) returns the specified x value with the right padding. This adds spaces to the front.<n>end<n><n>p findNthDigit 6 #=> "       6"<n>p findNthDiv( 99) #=> "     6"<n>```<n>## Instruction:complete the function so that it can return 1 if the given string starts with vowel or zero if the given string doesn't.<n>```<n>def isVowel(string)<n> string ==?       => Return 1, if given string starts with vaues or 0, if does not<n> string =~ /[aeiou]/ => return vaues in given string and if it return 1<n> string =~ /[yaeiou]/ if it return 1, else return 0<n>end<n>p isVowel "sale is avaliable" #=> 1<n>p isVowel  "apple is big"  #=> 0<n>```<n><n>## Instruction : complete the function `get_max_word` so that it can take a string variable and return the maximum word contained within the given string, and print `word` and its maximum count in the output variable `word_count`. The length of each word is given by word_len.  <n>```<n>def get_max_word word, word_len<n> max_word="max_word"<n> <n>  word =~/ /         # split the characters from spaces<n>  max_word = word.split(" ")[0]     ##split the string and print 0 and 1 to the print statement<n> unless max_word=="max_word"    # check if condition is true<n>     max_word="max"<n>    word_count = 1 #count is 1 for each charcater of the word<n>    if max_word =~/./{ #if its a number <n>      max_word = Integer(max_word)<n>  }<n>   ## if the charcater is number print 3 to get its actual count and do the same for 'i" <n>    else <n>     if max_word =~ /[i]/<n>     max_word = 3

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Output: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Output: 6<n><n>Input:The man didn't like getting out of bed and stepping on the cold tile, so where did he put carpeting? Choices:  A: houses B: bedroom C: istanbul D: open tress E: gym<n>Output:		A<n><n>Input: The woman didn't like getting into her car every day and stepping on the hot floor mat, so where did she put carpeting?Choices:  A: bedroom B: Istanbul C: istanbul-carpet D: car E: garage<n>Output: D<n><n>Input: The man wanted to go home from the store, so where did he park?Choices:  a) his car at the garage b) a hotel on vacation c)the garage d)the car E: gym<n><n>Output: B<n><n>Input: The doctor got a call from a patient on Monday, so where did he go?Choices: 1) the office 2) a resturant 3.)hotel 4)a bus station E) hospital<n>Output: E<n><n>Input: There are 8 children in the picture, but we count them 7 times. How many children are in the picture?<n>Output: 9 <n><n>#Code:<n>```<n>def getSum(arr):<n>    res = 0<n>    for i in arr:<n>        res +=i<n>    return res<n>```<n>```<n>def main():<n>    print("Answer:",getSum("Janet has 9 cards. Mara has twice Janet's cards and Brenda has 48 cards. Mara has 25 cards.".split(".")))<n>```
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Output: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Output: 6<n><n>Input:What is something that you feel when you go to the opera? Choices:  A: fall asleep B: headache C: boredom D: relaxation E: sick<n>Output:		relaxation<n><n><n>### You can also change your answer in this question if the program gives incorrect output after the correct output<n><n>Input: How many months are in a year?<n>Output: 12<n><n>### Instruction:The output of the programs should look like the outputs. The output can be single line or a list of lines.<n><n>Input: Write a small program that prints three-digit numbers in ascending order.  The first number should be 001, followed by 002, 003,..., 999.<n>Output:  The program should print the list of numbers displayed.<n><n>Input:  Write a small program that reads a string, finds repeated characters inside the string and prints the number of times each character is repeated. Sample output:<n><n>Example-1: Input: Hello<n>Example-2: Output: 2<n>Example-3: Input: Hello, world<n>Example-4: Output: 2, 5<n><n>Input: Write code for the following problem: Use the + operator and the int data type to do math with characters and integer values. This data type can represent numbers, so perform arithmetic. Your program should print the result (addition statement) at the end. Sample Input:<n><n>Example-5: 3 + 6<n>Example-6: 14 + 28<n>Sample Output:<n>Example-7: 4 + “3”<n>Example-8: 5 + “6”<n><n>Example-9: 7 + 8<n><n>Input: 3 + "hello" + "java"<n>Output: 2344579<n><n><n>Example-10: 10 - "123"<n>Sample Output: -23<n><n>Instruction:  Write a program for checking two numbers, if both are prime numbers or one of them a prime number. Input : number = 4<n>Output :  Output : Prime?<n>Sample Output :  number = 4<n>Prime?<n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Output: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Output: 6<n><n>Input:Where would you find a desk normally occupied by a young person? Choices:  A: office building B: schoolroom C: library D: bedroom E: gym<n>Output:		B<n><n>Input:  A: office<n>B: library<n>C: schoolroom<n>D: gym<n>E: bedroom<n><n>Input:  How many days in the week contain T? (T stands for Thursday or Thurs., depending on the dictionary you use.)<n><n>Output: 7<n><n>Input: A farmer has 3 sons and 3 daughters. If 2 fathers and 2 daughters are his sons and daughters, respectively, how many parents does he have, all told?<n>Output: 4<n><n>Input: How many pencils did you buy.<n><n>Output: 18<n><n>#Solution<n><n>```python<n>"""<n>Author:   Jake D.<n>Source:   https://www.reddit.com/r/dailyprogrammer/comments/3hf6kb/12222014_3_of_69_102_104/<n>Link:   https://www-reddit-com.ezproxy.bu.edu/comments/3h9y42/3_of_6_9_10_2_10_4/cb0i06n?context=3<n>"""<n>def solution(n=20): <n>     total = n<n>     answer = 1<n>     x = n - total<n>     while(x >= 0):<n>        n = n-1<n>        answer = n//10 + 10*answer<n>        x = n-1<n>     return answer<n>``` <n><n><n>

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Output: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Output: 6<n><n>Input:What is a common sign that someone is lying? Choices:  A: ordering dog food online B: avoid eye contact C: feel guilty D: fall asleep E: blush<n>Output:		E<n><n>## Solution<n><n>```swift<n>import Foundation<n>print(20 * 15)<n><n>print("How many blocks did Pete walk in all?")<n><n>var walkAmt = 0<n>var walkDist = 10<n><n>if walkDist < 20 {<n>    walkAmt = walkDist<n>}<n><n>while walkAmt < 50 {<n>    if (walkDist > 20) {<n>        walkAmt += 10<n>    }<n>    else {<n>        walkAmm += 5<n><n>    }<n>}<n>print(walkAmt)<n><n>print("What is a common sign someone is lying?")<n><n>var resultAnswer = ""<n>for i in 0..< 5 {<n><n>    let x = Int.random(in: 0... 5)<n>    switch x {<n>    case 0:<n>        resultAnswer = "A: ordering food online"<n>    case 1:<n>        resultAnswer += " B: avoid eye contact"<n>    case 2:<n>        resultAnswer.append(" C: feel guilty")<n>    case 3:<n>        resultAnswer [.index(before:.endIndex)] += " D: fall asleep"<n>    case 4:<n>        resultAnswer.append(" E: blush \n")<n>    default:<n>        print("Something Went Wrong, please try again,")<n>    }<n>}

It has 292 pages.<n>How many lines of text are in Moby Dick?<n><n>Output: 39<n><n>    <br>Hint 1: A line has 1 letter.<n><n>    <br><br><n>    <br>Input: The ratio of girls to boys in a math class is 3:2. If there are 35 in the class, how many are girls?<n><n>    <br >output: 17<br<n><n><n>#### Write a for loop by dividing the question by "for i in list:", then add three lines where we use for i in list: to make a for loop that counts up from 1 to list.length-.<n><n>The for loop prints each value in the sequence starting at 1 and incrementing by 1, and ending with the last value in the sequence.<n><n>Input: What should be put in this for loop? How should the for loop add each of the values from 1 to 48 to get the sum?<n><n>for i in list: print(i)<n><n>You should put i<n><n>    for i in list:<n>        print(i)<n>        sum += i<n><n>Input: Add the following line before and after the for loop to get the answer.<n><n>  for i in list: print (i)<n>  sum += i<n>  print (sum)<n><n>Input: Bring the sum line after the for loop but before the print (sum) line to get the answer<n><n>for i in [1,2,3]+[4,5]:<n>    print (i)<n>    sum += i<n><n>Output: 10<n><n><n>####Instruction:Answer the following problem.<n><n>    <p> Input: Everybody has a little bit<n>    of creativity, but <b>only</b><n>    a few lucky ones <b>get to</b><n>    do <u>what</u> for a living?<n>    Choices:   A: sew   B: create art   C: express yourself   D: sing and<n>    dance   E: write</p><n>

Choices:  A: drugstore B: hospital C: bedroom D: car E: house<n>Output:		A<n><n># Program S.HARNESS  :<n># Program for using Harness Algorithm to find H_n function<n><n><n># Define variables.<n><n>def n:<n>    input("Enter number of elements in the array");<n>    return int(input("Enter number of elements = " + str(input("Enter number elements"))))<n><n><n>def P_n:<n>    input("What is element size?");<n>    return int (input("Element size in an array is = " + str(P_n))) # P_n stores number of elements in the matrix M<n><n>def K_n:<n>    return 1;<n><n>def M_n:<n>    M_n=0<n>    for item in range(0, P_n):<n>        for i in range(0, n): # i stands for item<n>            for j in range(0,n): # j stands for item<n>               M_n += abs(i - j)<n>        print("M_n is = "+str(M_n)) #M_n stores the values of item where i=j<n><n>def Harne_function(K):<n>    temp = 0<n>    N = 0 <n>    for i in range(2):<n>        K_n = 0<n>        M_n = 0 # K is value of M_n<n>        for j in range (0, N+1):<n>            M_n = (M_n *K) % 10 #M_n stores value = ( M * K, where M is a function of number of element in the array and K is a constant) <n>        M_n += P[i] #P[i] is the size of item[i]<n>        print(M_n)<n>        N+= 1 #N increases by 1 for each iteration of the loop<n>        temp = temp + abs (M_n)  # temp is a temporary variable, it is used to store sum of the value which <n>        temp = temp % (9777)       #modulo operation<n>        temp = temp // K #This formula is given in the book<n>        print(temp) #This is a modified formula as in the book, it is written temp = temp % (7777)<n>        if temp >= K:<n>            print("M is "

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Output: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Output: 6<n><n>Input:What is the opposite of foolhardy? Choices:  A: thoughtful B: discreet C: calculated D: cautious E: careful<n>Output:		careful<n><n><n><n>### Solution :<n><n>1. <n><n>```python<n>def cards(a,b,c):<n>      if (b-a)>c: return a+c+1<n>      else: return b-c+1<n> <n>ans=cards(9,19,28)<n>```<n><n>2. <n><n>```<n>def blocks(a,b):<n>      if (a-b)>0: return a-b<n> <n>ans=blocks(5,20)<n><n>```<n><n>3. <n><n>``` <n>def chairs(a,b,count):<n>      new_b=count//count(b-a)<n>      new=b-count<n>      sub=sub-count<n>      if new==sub:<n>         return a+count<n>       new_a=a-new<n>       if new_a<0: new_a=0<n>       ans=new_a<n> <n>count=count-7<n>ans=chairs(10,3,count)<n>print(ans)<n> <n> <n> <n>```<n><n>4. <n>                                                 5 <n>```<n>import datetime<n><n>def coffee (amount,thermoses):<n>      cups_used=2<n>      ans=amount-cups_used<n>      return ans<n> <n>cups=coffee(4.5,18)<n>print(cups)<n> <n>```<n>5. <n>```<n>if (c=='thoughtful'): return 'foolhardy'<n> <n>ans='cautious'<n>```<n>

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Output: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Output: 6<n><n>Input:Why would someone confess to committing murder? Choices:  A: guilty conscience B: fear C: go free D: problems E: find god<n>Output:		A<n><n>Input:  A dog will sit if its owner says “sit!” and the dog will stand up if its owner says “stand up!” If the owner commands the dog to sit, the dog obeys. A person cannot command the dog to stand up unless the dog is sitting. Will the person command the dog to stand? Can the owner command the dog to “sit” at every command? Explain your answers<n>Output: True and False<n><n>#### Part 2<n><n>Input: When three girls go down a hallway, they say, “This looks like a mousetrap.” Which girl says the mousetrap?<n>Output: The one who is walking with the others<n>```<n>Sample Input:<n>4 * 4 + 5 + 4<n>4 ** 2 - 4 + 3 + 3<n>4 / 2 - 3 + 4 * 5 - 7 * 2<n>8 * (4 * 5 - (7 * 2)) + 4 * 9<n>2191<n>40 <n>7 * 20 <n>7 <n>Honest <n>False```<n><n>

The concept of fractions was first introduced to calculate "a" and "b" which were numbers. When we added all the choices together we found that the only choice that made sense was 1/3. The question then asked the student to round the answer to the nearest 10. That is why 4 rounded was the answer because 1/3 * 4 rounded ==.33 rounded == 4 rounded == 4.<n><n> Input 3<n><n><n>Input 4<n><n>The question asked for the ways of placing 6 dots on a floor to form a triangle while no two dots were equal. <n><n>First the student should put an "S" shaped curve in the middle of the floor with the dots touching the other two. That is why 15 was the correct answer.<n><n><n>Input5<n><n>In this question I used a combination of division and exponentiation. Choices:  A: downtown area B: urban area C: new york city D: shopping mall E: military base<n>Output:		Urban area<n><n>### Solution<n><n>## Step 1 (Expose the problem statement)<n><n>Asks user to input the problem statement.<n><n>![Untitled image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/61884891/132122828-e0e0390d-17d6-4540-a480-73d2c846027e.JPG)<n><n>## Step 2 (Check if the answer is within acceptable range)<n>If the correct answer is below 50, this message will show:<n><n>Too low, please enter a higher value.<n><n>![Uuntitled image](https://github.com/Nico-2022-Summer-Codesprint1/Code/blob/main/assets/check_answer.JPG)<n>![Untitled Image](https://github.githubassets.com/images/modules/logos_mark/gitignore_mark.png)<n><n>If the correct answer if greater than 50, it will show the following answer:<n><n>Too high, please enter a lower value.<n><n>![image](https://user-Images.githubusercontent.cOm/6188 4891/Download/2315142e-e482-46b1-8201-e8ce2a a6885a_image.png)<n><n>## Step3 (Check if the answer if greater than 200, otherwise the incorrect answer)<n><n>If the answer is greater than 20<n>      **Correct answer**: 200<n>Otherwise, the incorrect answer will be given<n><n>## Step 4 (output the correct answer to the user)<n>**Output the correct answer to the users:**<n>The correct answer is: 50<n>

Then count() takes the result and produces a new column, which holds the total of the number.<n>- Using plyr's mutate, summarize, and count() functions, calculate the number of students with an “A” grade.<n>- Summarize() and mutate() take the same parameters. The only different is that summarize() creates a single value (like the sum or a count), while mutate() creates a new column.<n><n>- For example, the statement mutate(grade, A = sum(grade >= 90)) creates a new column named A with each row’s grade >= 90 in a vector. <n><n>- Next, plyr's count() function takes a variable as the argument, and counts the values stored in that column. The resulting variable, named count, is a vector.<n>- <n>- It takes the number of students who have achieved an “A” out of the total number (67) of students.<n>- Here’s the final result:<n><n>```{r}<n><n>grade <- c(9
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet.
