The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Output: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Output: 6<n><n>Input:Where do you put your grapes just before checking out? Choices:  A: mouth B: grocery cart C: super market D: fruit basket E: fruit market<n>Output:		B<n><n>Input:Choose a country.  A: China B: United States C: Russia D: Mexico E: France <n>Output: A<n><n>Input: 50 miles was divided among 20 vehicles. How many miles were left to each vehicle? Choices:  Choose a value from [0, 50]. A: 2.6 B: 2.5 C: 2.4 D: 2.3 E: 2.2<n>Output: C<n><n>Input: The length of a room is 7 meters longer than its width. How many meters wide is the room, in all? Choices: 3 A: 6 7 B: 7 6 C: 7 5  D: 7 4 E: 6 2<n>Output: A<n>Input: 21 - 3 = A: 28 B: 29 C: 30 D: 31<n>Output: A<n>"""<n>import unittest<n>import random<n>import copy<n><n>class Solution825(object):<n>    def threeSum(self, nums):<n>        """<n>        :type nums: List[int]<n>        :rtype: List[List[int]]<n>        """<n>        nums.sort()<n>        result = []<n>        for i in range(len(nums)):<n>            for j in range(i+1, len(nums)):<n>                for k in range(j+1, len( nums)):<n>                    if (nums[i] + nums[j] + nums[k] == 0):<n>                        if ( nums[i] == nums[j]):<n>                            m = abs( nums[i] - nums[j] )<n>                        else:<n>                            m = nums[i] + ( -nums[j] ) <n>                        if (k+1 <= len( nums)):                            <n>                            n = nums[k+1]<n>                            if n-n <= -m-m:<n>                                m -= n<n>                            elif n-n <= m+m:<n>                                if nums[k] + n <= nums[i]:<n>                                    m += n<n>                                else:<n>                                    m -= n<n>

How many more pounds does the llama weigh than the average weigh of the 2 animals?<n>Output:13.5 pounds more<n><n>Instruction:You may use any one 2-digit number that can be divided exactly by 25.<n>For example, you may use 18 because 18=7×2, or 12 because 12=3×4, or 19 because 19=19, or 24 because 24=4×6, or 31 because 31=2×15,<n>or 35 because 35=5×7<n>Input:The number 294.<n>Output:591<n><n>Input:29430<n>Output:915 <n><n>

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Output: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Output: 6<n><n>Input:The game was on sale.  I got it then because it was usually what? Choices:  A: buying B: purchase C: overpriced D: way to much E: expensive<n>Output:		Answer: Buying<n><n>Input:Jim spent $39. How much was one dollar for Jim?<n>Output: Answer: 1/0.39 dollars.<n><n>Input:How many times is 39 more two than 72?<n>Output: Answer 11<n><n>Input:"I am 20 times more than 3". Is it correct? Choices: 1: Yes. 2. No. 3: True 4: False. 5: Unclear.<n>Output: Answer: False.<n><n>Input:"I weighed 62 pounds as a child. I gained 12 pounds by last year."  How much do I weigh now?<n>Output: Answer:-30<n><n>Input: You have 6 apples. You gave 1/2 of what you had. How many do you have now?<n>Output:Answer: 1<n><n>Input:How is 7.2 liters more than 2.4 in gallons?<n>Output: Answer=1.75<n><n>Input:I bought six apples. I ate one. Each apple contains 5 pieces. How many pieces of apples do I have?<n>Output:Answer=4<n><n>Input: The store sold 20 more pens than pencils. I bought 22 pens. How many pencils did I buy?<n>Output:Answer:=16<n><n>Input: I have $222. How much is 50 % of $222?<n>Output:Answer:$22<n><n>Input: You drove 225 miles south. You then drove 185 miles east. You stopped to eat lunch, and then drove 85 miles north, and then 125 miles east. How many miles did you drive?<n>Output:Answer=$400<n><n>Input: I traveled 330 feet north. I traveled 250 feet east, and then I traveled 70 feet north. I finished my trip when I walked 190 feet east. How many miles of my trip were east?<n>Output:$171

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Output: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Output: 6<n><n>Input:John moved away from his family.  He was a bit upset that he had to do it, but he needed the job.  Still, he would have preferred it if the job were what? Choices:  A: present B: stay here C: closer D: available E: come here<n>Output:		A<n><n>---<n>Author: Jace Stanton<n>Created: Thu, May 10, 2018, 2:15 AM CST<n><n><n>### Answer:<n><n>### EXPLANATION:<n><n>1:  Janet=brenda- 10=brenda [number to be subtracted]<n>m:mar=2j=4<n>=4-2=2 more<n>1=10=211<n><n>2:  Pete walked 5blocks,  then took bus to postoffice<n>[subtract 2 blocks=7]<n>50= 20+10<n>50=30<n>30=60<n>60=20+40<n>50=20+50<n>total=70<n><n>3:  Janet's,green's, and white's=blue, green, white=combine<n>10x3=10<n>5-3=1<n>4+13=17<n>22-17=5<n>19=7<n>13+5=18:thermoses=18<n>5x3=15=janet<n>3x3=9=green<n>10+9+18=37=white's<n>40+30=70=green=10<n>3x3=4<n><n>5:  John was upset he had to move away

Choices:  A: artist junkyard B: music store C: singing D: symphony E: orchestra<n>Output:		orchestra<n><n>Input:What is the capital of South Korea? Choices: A: Seoul B: Hong Kong C: Tokyo D: Beijing E: Paris<n>Output: Seoul<n><n>### 100 marks<n><n>### Problem 1:<n><n>#### Question: In a city, there are cars, trucks, and buses.  The number of cars is 3 times the number of trucks, and the number of buses is 5 times the number of trices. If there are 183 vehicles in all, how many trucks are there in the city?<n><n> <n><n>#### Answer:<n><n>| Solution | Comments                 | Explanation                                                     |<n>| -------- | ------------------------ | ------------------------------------------------------------ |<n>| 32      | Input: The city has 183 vehicle which are divided into cars, trucks and buses. 3 times more than trucks and 5 times less buses than the cars. Answer: 32 |<n><n>#### Question:<n><n>#### Question#2:<n><n>#### Question #3:<n><n>#### Question :<n><n>#### Question : <n><n>Question<n><n>Question 2<n><n>### Problem2:<n><n>#### 2.1  In a company, there are 6 executives on the board. The executives are arranged in the following  way: They sit in groups of 2, 4, 7, 6, 2, and 2 people. How many people go to the company?<n><n>#### 2..2. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Output: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. Choices:  A: cause death B: cause bleeding C: falling down D: become infected E: claim insurance<n>Output:		D<n><n><n>---<n><n>### Instruction 2:<n>Answer the following multiple choice problem.<n><n>Input: The ratio of boys to girls in a class is 1:2. 44 girls and 32 boys are in the class. How many are in the class, including the ones who aren't there?<n>Output: 76<n><n>---<n><n># Import data<n>---<n><n>## Import data from a file<n>```<n>import sys<n>import csv<n>import numpy as np<n>import random<n>data = sys.argv[1]<n>```<n><n># Coding<n>## Question 1<n>```<n># This program will read in data from a file and give you the solution to the question.<n><n>def main():<n>    pass<n>    print ("Hello there")<n>    with open(data, newline=")") as csvfile:<n>        spamreader = csv.reader(csvfile)<n>        n = 0<n>        count = "0"<n>        #Get number of girls<n>        for i in spamreader:<n>            if i[1] == "g":<n>                n = n + 1<n>        while not spamreader.next():<n>            if spamreader.next()[1] == "b":<n>                n = 0<n>            if n == 89:<n>                #print (spamreader.next())<n>                break<n>                pass<n>            #print (spam reader.next())<n>        ratio = n / (90 - 30)<n>        print (r "(" + str(ratio) + ")(" + str(count) + ")" )<n>        #if ratio < 0.5:<n>        #    return True<n>        #else:<n>        #    pass<n>        return True<n>main()<n>```<n><n># Results<n>## Question 1:<n>Given that there are <n><p> 43 girls and 32boys</p><n><p> What is the ratio of boys:girl?</p><n><h3> The answer: </h3><n><p> 1/2:1</p><n>And that would mean<n><p> 21 of the 90 people would be girls and 90-21 = 69 would be boys.<n><n># Question 2:<n>In a class

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. Choices:  A: bee hive B: england C: castle D: deck of cards E: chess game<n>Output:		Answer D<n><n>### Solution:<n>![Image Example][image-example]<n><n>```<n>def solution(firstList, secondList)<n>    return 0 if (firstList.length == 0) || (secondList.length == 1)<n><n>    # Sum of firstList and secondList length equals 1<n>    if (firstList.first + secondList.first == 3)<n>        # If length of firstList is equal to number in firstList<n>        return 1 if (secondList.first == firstList.first) && <n>                     (firstList.first == firstListItem.sum + secondList.first)<n><n>        # If length is greater than number in firstList<n>            <n>    else if (firstList.sum >= secondList.first && firstList.first * 2 == secondList.sum)<n>        # If number of secondList does not matter <n>        return 2 if (secondList.second == 0)<n><n>        # Return number for each secondList and secondList length if the number of secondList does matter<n><n>    else<n>        # If a secondList length greater than number in secondList return a number is not specified<n>        return 3<n><n>end<n>```<n># Solution:<n>```<n>def printTheTotal(firstList, thirdList, fifthList, secondList) <n>    return 0 unless (firstList.length!= 0)<n><n>    # Find the total if the firstList length does not matter<n>    if (firstItem.length == 3) <n>        print The answer is <n>        print 1 if (thirdList.first == 5 && secondList.first == firstItem.sum + thirdList.first)<n>        print 2 if (fifthList.first == 4 && secondList.first * 4 && 3 == (secondList.first || thirdList.first || firstItem.first))<n>        print 3<n>    # If total does not matter<n>    else<n>        print 4<n>    end <n>end<n><n>def getTheTotal_helper(firstList, secondlist, thirdList, fifthlist)<n><n>    # if the number the number is too big<n>    if (fifthList <= 0) || (fifthList >= firstItem.sum)<n>        return 0 unless (fourthList.length!= 1)

How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Output: 6<n><n>Input:What place is not interesting to children? Choices:  A: classroom B: toy store C: school D: soccer game E: dinner<n>Output:		D<n><n>In the example: B and D are the same. A, B D E A, B, C, D E, and E are not the same because of the word order.<n><n>### Instruction: Your assignment is to write a function called sum that reads a sequence of two integers from the keyboard and <n>returns the sum of the integers entered.<n><n>```<n><n>### Sample Program for Solution:<n><n>def sum(i, j):<n>    return i + j<n><n>```<n><n># Challenge 1 : sum the even numbers<n><n>```<n><n>from operator import add<n><n>def even(i):<n>    even = []<n>    for j in range(i):<n>        if j % 2 == 0:<n>            even.append(j)<n>    return even<n><n><n>def odd_2d_count():<n>    return(even(i) + add(even(j), even(k)))<n><n><n>def sum(sum):<n>    i = 0<n>    for j in sum:<n>        i = i + j<n>        j = 0<n>    return i<n><n><n>def sum_and_average_even(sum) :<n>    even = 0<n>    even_sum = 0<n>    avg = 0<n>    total = 0<n>   <n>    for i in sum :<n>        total = total + i<n>        even = even + sum.index(i)<n>        even_sum = even_sum + i<n>    <n>    avg = (even_sum/even)<n>    return avg<n>```<n><n># Question 1: In this function, the name of the variable, sum, is a little confusing. How can you rename it in a way that is clearer for the function's name to use?<n><n>```<n>sum_number_of_odd = 0<n>```<n>sum = 0<n>```

How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Output: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Output: 6<n><n>Input:A shower is an expected amenity when you reserve a what? Choices:  A: gy mnasiu m B: motel room C: seashore D: bath room E: locker room<n>Output:		bath room<n><n>Input: A baseball batting helmet is a what? Choices A: bobble hat B: hat C: ball D: earmuff E: mitt<n>Output: bobble hat<n><n>Input: A person can use the same pair of what at a time for different what?<n>    Choices A: glovesB: mittens C: slippers D: shoes E: shorts<n>Output: shoes<n><n># Input: Janet has 19,479 coins more than Brenda. Brenda has four times as many coins as Mara. They all have a total of 7,598 coins. How many coins does Mara have?<n>Output: 13,881<n><n>## Solution<n># A classroom is the place a class is held<n><n># In the first example, there are 10 blue, 3 times as many green, but only 13 fewer than the green and blue combined.<n># 10 + 3(3) = 13<n># (13) + 3(10) = 67<n># So there are 67 chairs total.<n><n># In the third example, Genevieve drank up 3/18ths of the 4.5 gallon supply<n># 3(18/4.5) = 6 pints<n><n><n><n><n><n>

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Output: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Output: 6<n><n>Input:while luck plays a big role, every person who is great at something has focus and what to it? Choices:  A: hatred B: surprised C: compliments D: dedication E: solutions<n>Output:		D<n><n>Input: A, B, C, D and E all go into a coffee shop for breakfast. A has a cup of tea and a piece of cake. B and C each have a cup of coffee and C has a cinnamon roll. D has a cup of coffee and 3 donuts. E has a cup of coffee. How much money is spent on breakfast?<n>Output: $12.00<n><n>----------------------------------------------<n>### My solution:<n>#### 1<n>### Answer: 211:<n><n>Instructions: If Mara has one 40 cards.<n><n>Then Mara - 40<n>= Mara - 41<n>= Mara - (42-41)<n>= Mara - (-1):<n><n>1. Mara - 4<n>2. Mara - 3<n>3. Mara - 2<n>4. Mara - 1<n>Mara - 1<n><n>#### 3<n>### Answer:  67<n><n>Instractions: (3 * 4); (4 - 13) = 63<n><n>413 * 4 = 253+168<n><n>13 * (4-5) = 62<n><n>63+62 = 67.<n><n>#### 5<n>### Answer: (3/8) * 8 = 5/8 * 8 + 1/8 * 8<n><n>Instractions :<n><n>(5 * 8) = (4 * 8) + (1 * 8)<n><n>(45) + (9) = (32) + (9)<n><n>Instractions;<n>A. 32+9<n><n>B. (21 + 7)<n><n>C. 11<n><n>D. 12<n><n>E. 0 :<n><n>A,C, and E would be the right answe.<n><n>#### 6<n>### Answer:6<n><n>Instractions ; Coffee is made<n>from a mixture of ground beans, water, and sugar<n><n>so; 12.00= 6+6 +1<n><n>

Choices:  A: from the sky B: map C: cross counties by car D: country E: michigan<n>Output:		E<n><n><n><n>**Answer:**<n><n>### Method:<n><n>- For the first question, the most logical answer is that Janet has 16 cards. <n><n>- For the second question, 150 is 60% the distance between 50 and 20, and since Mara has 44% as many cards, the answer is that her cards are 100% the distance between them, which is 10 cards. <n><n><n>### The only method I thought I've used in the second question is a percentage to compare numbers.<n><n>- For the third question, we compared the number of green chairs with the number of blue chairs because green chairs are 91 (3 times 10 of the blue chairs).  Also, 3 times and 13 divided by 3 times give the answer. <n><n>- In the last question, she used the ratio of 3 to 67, which is 18.<n>

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Output: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Output: 6<n><n>Input:HOw do you carry potatos home? Choices:  A: grocery store B: grocery bag C: restaurants D: farmer's market E: bushel basket<n>Output:		c<n><n>### Explanation<n>Instructions:<n>We first find the total sum of the cards that Brenda and Mara had.<n>Janet had cards more than Brenda, so we start with 9 and add the total cards between Brenda and Janet to the sum.<n>Mara has twice as many cards than Janet, so we double Janet's card number and add the rest which is the total card count.<n>So the three cards that Brenda, Janet and Mara have are equal to - 9 + 2 * 9 + 150 = 211<n>The answer is 9.6 is correct.<n><n>Explanation: Input:<n>Instructions: We first multiply the number of blocks in 5 because we use blocks to measure the travel. Next, we subtract the number of blocks for the bus and also the number of blocks he used going home.<n>5 * 20 - 5 + 5 = 50<n><n>Explanation 2:<n>Input:<n>Instructions :<n>We find the total number of blue chairs in the room. Now, we solve the math equation to find the number of green chairs in the room and the white chairs in the room as we subtracted the number of green chair from the total blue chairs in the classroom.<n>Now, the number of chairs in the room is the sum of the green chair and the white chair, but in math equations. White chair = Green chair - 3 and white chair = blue chair -3<n>Now, the total number of chairs in a classroom will be the sum of (green chair + white chair)<n><n>Input:<n><n>Instructions: The first question that must be answered is what do Genevieve drink? And what was the total amount she drank?<n>Genevieve drank 6 pints of coffee.<n><n><n>### Submission:<n>Fill out the below boxes.<n><img id='submit-gif' src=''/>

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Output: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Output: 6<n><n>Input:Where is a lion likely to live? Choices:  A: veldt B: ocean C: savannah D: africa E: jungle<n>Output:		A<n><n>  ## Explanations:<n>  <n>  #Example 1<n>  ### Instruction:<n>  #### Solution 1<n> <n>  9 – 9 = 0 <n><n>  150 – 40 = 110 <n><n>  #### Solution 2<n><n>  Janet cards: 9 + Brenda cards = 18 (100 - Brenda cards = 52) so Janet cards+Brenda cards=18, Brenda cards=52<n><n>  Janets and brenedas cards =211<n><n>  #### Solution3<n><n>  Janet, Brenda and Mara cards =18+211+150=440<n><n>  Thus, Janet had 18 cards, Brenda had 211 cards and Mara had 150 cards.<n><n>  #Example 2<n><n>  ### Instruction<n><n>  #### Solution<n><n>  Pete is still 5 blocks left from his house to the house.<n><n>    Total travelled distance = 20+5 = 25<n><n>  #### Solution2<n><n>  <n><n>  >There are 10 blue<n>chairs, green chairs are <n>3 times as many as<n>blue chairs, and there<n>are 13 fewer white<n>chairs than the green<n>and blue chairs combined. so, There white chairs =13-10<3 = 3 and green chairs = 10chairs and yellow chairs =3chains<n>So the chairs = 17<n><n>  #### Solution (Oddy)<n><n>  >Green chairs =10<n><n>  >Green and blue chairs combined =13+10 = 23<n><n>  >white chairs =13-(blue and green chairs =13 – 23=8<n><n>  >There total chairs=17<n>  <n>  #### Solution<n>  Cuz the number of gallons of coffee is in 4.5, so it will be divided to 18  so 18 * 4.5/1 = 4.5/ 18 and it is in litres, so the volume of water of pints is 3<n><n>  #### Remarks<n><n>  if the volume of water is

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Output: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Output: 6<n><n>Input:John is getting something important.  What does this make him feel? Choices:  A: then have B: headaches C: stoic D: being happy E: wanting more<n>Output:		 F = 11<n><n><img src="{{site.baseurl}}/app/assets/images/2019-06-1220-22-11-36.png" alt="1C" style="width:93%"><n><n>### Explanation:<n>Input: Janet's input is 14 and Brenda's is 9. Therefore, Mara has more than twice as many cards as Brenda. But Mara also has more than many cards as Janet and Janet has more than Brenda, so there's no way to get 150 and still have more than twice as many.<n><n>For the second one, it says Pete's input is 5 and his output is 50. If Pete is walking somewhere, that's the amount he's moving (his output).<n><n>I feel like the third one is wrong. How can the blue chair's input be 10? That doesn't make a lot of sense. They all share 5, which is 5 chairs. If the green chair needs to be increased by 3 times, that means the green chair needs to have 1.5, which is also 3 times 5, which is how many of the blue chairs there are. I'm assuming this is part of the problem, but I don't think it will be necessary for this quiz.<n><n>I think the fourth one is a trick question. How can Genevieve drink 3 thermoses, if she is the only person that did?<n><n>For the last one, it's probably an emoticon thing for being hungry. I think that's what they're going for. But since the code is messed up, I would probably look to see if there's a better way to solve the thing.<n><n>### Answer:<n>314<n>

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Output: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Output: 6<n><n>Input:What is a negative effect to someone other than a spouse when two spouses are getting divorced? Choices:  A: lot of grief B: depression C: no spouse D: lose money E: children suffer<n>Output:		B<n><n>Input: Choose the correct meaning of the word:  A: (adj) bad B: (adj) good C: (adj) kind D: (adj) helpful E: (adj) dangerous<n>Output: A<n><n><n><n><n>##<n><n># Solution:Part A.<n>### Code:<n>{% highlight javascript linenos %}<n>function solution(input){<n>    var answer;<n>    answer = input[0] * input[1];<n>    return answer;<n>}<n>{% endhighlight %}<n>### Explanation:<n><n>##<n><n>### Solution:Part B.<n>### Code<n>{% highlight javascript lineno %}<n>function solution(params) {<n>  var arr = params[0].split(",");<n>  var arr2 = params[1].split(" ");<n>  var answer = arr2.shift();<n><n>  var answer = parseInt(input[0])*input[1];<n>  if (arr[0]!== ""){<n>      answer = parseInt(answer)+parseInt(arr[0]);<n>  }<n><n>  if (arr2.length){<n>      answer += parseInt(arr2.shift());<n>  }<n><n><n>  answer = answer / parseFloat(arr2.pop())<n>  console.log('answer:' + answer);<n>}<n>{% endhighlithtm %}<n>{% highlight js %}<n>input0<n>output0<n>input1<n>output1<n>{% endhighlight %}

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Output: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Output: 6<n><n>Input:Where can you store a small notepad on your person? Choices:  A: back pocket B: meeting C: drug store D: home E: school<n>Output:		C<n><n>---<n><n>### Instruction:This section explains concepts which are not commonly found in data science.<n><n>Data science is not concerned with the study of calculus or differential equations. However, there are many concepts which you will need to know to help you develop your data science skills (e.g. matrix manipulation and linear algebra), which are often not found in standard data science textbooks.<n><n>This section addresses those concepts. <n><n>In order to help those who don't have a thorough knowledge of college algebra, this section will be split into 3 parts.<n><n>Part 1: Vectors<n><n>Part 2: Addition and Subtraction of Vectors<n><n>Part_3: Linear Algebra.<n><n>---<n><n># Part: 1<n><n># Vectors<n><n>There are several things that you will be called upon often in Data Science in order to accomplish simple mathematical tasks.<n><n>One such method of performing simple mathematical calculations is the **vector.**  A vector is simply a set of numbers, each of which is known by its corresponding index. <n><n>There are several ways to demonstrate the existence of a vector.  Most Data Scientists simply use a row of Xs as a vector but will list it as a number. The data you are working with is important in this regard.<n><n>In this case, we are interested in performing a subtraction in order to get our answer.<n><n>``` python<n>v1 = [7, 5, 2, -4]<n>v2 = [-4, 2, -5, 12]<n>difference = v1 - v2<n>print(difference)<n>```<n><n>``` python<n>difference = [-16, -7, 1, 7]<n>```<n><n>---<n><n>```python<n>difference = [n - 1 for n in v1]<n>print(difference<n><n>```<n><n>```python<n># The above code will result in this <n>difference = [0, -1, 2, 7]<n><n>```<n><n>--- <n><n>```python<n><n>from math import fsum,fsum2d<n>import numpy as np<n><n><n>difference = np.subtract(v1, v2,dtype: float)<n><n>print(difference.shape) # The shape will show as (5, )<n><n>```

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. Choices:  A: book B: meeting C: television D: guide E: newspaper<n>Output:		A = B = D = E<n><n>Input: 3/4 of the students in a class went to sleep last night. 120 students in the whole class went to sleep last. What is its LCM?<n>Output: 3200<n>Input: 12 x 100 + 15 = 49, 23/14 – 21 = 1/7<n><n>Input: The LCM=18, and the HCF=3.<n><n>Input: The HCF=12, and the LCM=24.<n><n>#### Solution<n><n>### Answer<n><n>#### Answer 1:<n><n>319<n><n>### Answer 2:<n><n>50<n><n>### Answer3:<n><n>527<n><n>### Answer4:<n><n>12<n><n>### Answer5:<n><n>229<n><n>### Solution of Problem of PTE<n><n>Input: Janes has 9 cards more dan Brenda. Mara haves twice as many cards as Jane. How many cards do the t have in all if Maras haves 40 cards les as 150<n>Output:211<n><n>#### Solution<n>  Janes+Brenda+Mara=10+30+40 = 80 cards<n>  Janes-Brenda+Mara - 9+2+40=211<n><n>### Answer of Next PTE Question<n><n>Input:  Pete walked 5 block from his house to the post office. He rode the bus20 block to the post office to the get stamps. Laters he came home the same. How many blocks did pete travel in all<n><n>Output: 5

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Output: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Output: 6<n><n>Input:Where above your kitchen sink could you store canned food? Choices:  A: cupboard B: oven C: grocery store D: pantry E: cellar<n>Output:		The right spot is in the pantry.<n><n>Input:How many gallons of gas are used driving from Miami to Orlando and from Orlando to Miami? Choice: 10000 miles 20000 miles<n>Output:There is 1000 miles from Miami to Orlando (A), and 1000 from Orlando to Miami (B). Then, there is (A + B) - 2000 - 1000 = 300 miles. You can buy 300 miles of gas for $20, so $20 would be used in the entire trip.

"0"+p : p<n>        alert(s)<n>        n=Math.floor( n / 10 )<n>        i++;<n>    }<n>}<n>wordNum(n)<n>```<n><n><a href="https://www.hackerearth.com/practice/alg

If the input is incompatible with a positive integer answer, an answer of 0 should be returned.<n><n>#!/usr/bin/python<n><n>from sys import *<n><n>cards = 0<n>name = 'unknown'<n><n>def guesscards(amount,user):<n>    if cards+1 >= amount:<n>        correctguess=False<n>    elif cards+1 == amount:<n>        cards += 1<n>        guessedword=cards<n>        cards = correctguess = False<n>    else:<n>        guessedword = cards<n>        cards += 2<n>        guessedword+2<n>        if(name == user):<n>            correctguess = True<n>    if(correctguess):<n>        print 'Correct guess!:'+ user +'has'+ guessedword +'cards.'<n>    else:<n>       print 'Incorrect guess. This user has'+ user +'cards. Please try again.'<n><n><n>while(True):<n>    guessedword = cards = amount = 0<n><n>    prompt = raw_input('input the username of the account you wish to guess> ')<n><n>    if(strcmp(name,prompt)==0):<n>        guesscards(9,prompt)<n>        break<n><n><n>    elif(prompt == 'exit'):<n>        break<n>    else:<n><n>        prompt = raw_input("What is the username?\n\t'Unknown' is the default.")<n><n>        if(strcmp(prompt,'unknown') == 0):<n>            guesscards(9,'unknown')<n>            break<n>        else:<n><n>            guesscards(amount,prompt)<n>            amount += 1<n>            break<n><n>#####<n><n><n>class Person(object):<n>    def __init__(self):<n>        self.name = None<n><n>    # @staticmethod<n>    def guesscard(amount,user):  #user is a string<n>        """<n>          Input: name the user, and the amount of guesses<n>          Return value: guessed amount of cards, or 0 if incompatible<n><n>        """<n>        guessedcards=0<n>        amount = int(amount)<n>        while True:<n>            guessedcards += 1  #however many guesses

If a player runs 13 bases and is caught, then what is it called when the player is able to get on base? Choices: 1. sacrifice 2. tagged 3. passed out 4. out 5. tagged out<n>Output: 4. Out.<n><n>Input:In a certain country, there are 3 types of currency that all have different value. 1 type is worth 3 of another type and 4 of the other type. How many of the most expensive type of currency is there if there are 118 units of the cheapest currency?<n>Output: 33<n><n>Input:At 8:30 AM, a man in Phoenix traveled 1% of the way to Los Angeles. At 9 PM, he traveled another 46% of the distance to Los Angeles. What percent of the the way did he travel between 8:30 when he started, and when he reached Los Angeles?<n>Output: 40%<n><n>Input:How many different four-digit numbers are there if each of the digits from 0-9 can be used three times each?<n>Output: 10000<n><n>Input:If a chicken is eating an egg, and the egg is worth 4 dollars, and the chicken in eating it whole, and the chicken costs 6 dollars, how much is it worth when the chicken is finished eating the egg?<n>Output: 8<n><n>Input:Dolly has 12 hats. For every hat that she sells, she keeps one hat and gives away another. If she has 12 huts after she is done, how many did she give away?<n>Output: 0<n><n>Input:Two men stand at a distance from each other and each of them walk to the center until they cross paths. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Output: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Output: 6<n><n>Input:What do customers do in a store? Choices:  A: hunt B: pay merchants with money C: mail orders D: spend money E: demand satisfaction<n>Output:		I<n>Input: In a small town of 365 residents, there are 341 automobiles, 288 houses, and 155 apartments.<n>The ratio of the number of automobiles to the number of apartments is closest to:<n>Output: 1<n><n>## Solution <n>### Instruction:Answer the question that follows.<n><n>Input: In which case does the output equal `input1` and the input equal `input2`?<n><n>Output:  When `input1=100` and `input2=2`, the output is `input=3`.<n>### Instruction : Answer the question that follows. <n><n>Input: Find the value of `x` given the statements: `Ax=2`  and `Bx=-3`.<n><n>Output: 4<n>### Instruction <n>Answer the question that follows<n>Input: What are the expressions?<n>Output:  `s[n] + s[1]` and `sum1 (s[n] – first (s[1]))`.<n>### Instructions<n>Instructions:For the rest of the questions you need to solve for  or. <n><n>### Instruction Use variables to represent the parts of the puzzle you constructed. Then construct a formula whose value is the same as that of  and .<n><n>Input: <n><n>Output: <n><n><n>### Instructins: Express the puzzle as two equations and two inequalities. Then use these equations and inequalities to solve for the values of the variables.<n><n>Input: 17  = 111<n>32   = 666<n>21   = 22<n>25   = 667<n>34   = 777<n><n>Output: 61, 72, 52<n><n>### Instructins : For the rest of the puzzles you only need to be able to do the first set of steps. So, for this puzzle, you can replace variables and x in and with  but not y in  .<n><n>Input: Solve for b and c using x = 1  and x = 2<n><n>Output: b= 7 and c= -6<n><n>### Instrutcion:<n>Instructions:Use what you have learned so far

How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Output: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Output: 6<n><n>Input:Where would you buy a ticket to sit in a room with a lot of chairs facing the same direction? Choices:  A: conference B: theater C: building D: floor E: church<n>Output:		conference<n><n>### Solution:I use 4 steps to solve this problem.<n><n>Step 1:<n><n>For step 1, it is clear that I have a sequence of numbers <n>Let me assign them all to the variables<n><n>$s_1,s_2,s_3,s_4, s_5$<n><n>$m_1,m_2,m_3,m_4\ \ \ $<n><n>$c_1,c_2,c_3,c_4, c_5$<n><n>Step 2:<n><n>$$s_1 - m_2 + c_3 - m_4 + m_3 - s_5 = 5$$<n><n>And this can be rewritten as<n><n>$$-s_1 + m_2 + c3 + m_4 - s_5 =5$$<n><n>$$+s_4 - m_1 - m_3 = m_2 + c5$$<n><n>Step 3:<n><n>This is the step where I need a little bit of guesses. My guess is that I need to subtract $m_1$ from both sides.<n><n>So I guess:<n><n>$$-m_1 + m2 + c_3 + c_4 + m_4 = m_2 ... $$<n><n>Step 4:<n><n>Well, after step 3, I can say something that<n><n>$ m_4 $ <n><n>and I know that<n><n>$m_4 + m_2 + m_3 + c_3 + m_4 + m^5 + c_4= 180$<n><n>So I will replace the value of $m_4 $ and $m_2   m_3   c_3$ by my guess in step 3<n><n>And then this is my final answer.<n><n>$9.5$

How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Output: 6<n><n>Input:Wanting to avoid the cabbage spoiling, where did he put it? He drove 35 miles. How far did he travel that day?<n>Output: 375<n><n>Input: The average score on the exam was 80% and the average for the class is 85%. If 125 students took the exam, how many students got below 80%?<n>Output: 1<n><n>Input: In 3 hours, Jim rode 15 minutes to Danny's house on his bike, and he rode 12 minutes to the library. He walked 6 hours past Danny's house, then he walked 3 hours from the library to his house. How far did he walk in all?<n>Output:(Note, in order to pass a block, it must travel in the same direction for the entirety of the block.)<n>Jim rode for 3 hours, so that he covered 12 x 3 =36 minutes, and walked 6 hours, so that he did not walk the entire 36 minutes, and instead a part of the 6 hours - 36 minutes (3 hours and 28 minutes), or 28/60 = 0.467 minutes. He has walked for 46.7 minutes, and thus has only one possible walk length - the entire 46.7, so to be precise<n>Jim covered 58 miles all together walking and biking. 58/1.95 = 29.5, and thus Jim has only 29.5 minutes to bike. This 15 minutes + 29.5 = 44.5 minutes, thus he did ride for 44.5 and biked for 29.5. Jim has only 25.5 minutes to walk. So he walks for 25.5/46.7 = 0.554 miles or exactly 50 feet.<n><n><n><n>input:The car drove 21 hours and 200 miles at 7 mph. The man drove 13 hours and 4 miles at 6 mph. How many hours did it take for them to arrive at their destination?<n>output:(Their car drove 169 miles per

A: no handle  B: red  C: green  D: yellow  E: a screw on the end <n>Output:/red<n>```<n><n>#### Question 1:<n><n>Answer is : 8, or more<n><n>Explanation<n><n>A > B > C > D > E<n><n>```<n><n>### Question 2:<n><n>Answer is: 55<n><n>Explanation:<n><n>A * B = 100<n><n>A * B * C = 150<n><n>40 * B = A - 100<n>5 * B = A -150<n><n>50 =  (-100) 5 * (-5)<n><n>```<n><n>```<n><n><n>## 4. MATH<n><n>### Question:Which answer is closer, 999.9 or 1000<n><n>Answer is:1000<n>```<n><n>"""<n><n>## 5.LOGIC<n><n>### Question number 1:<n><n>Explanation is : 4<n><n>Number of combinations of k elements from a set (n) is given by the sum of (k) factorial:<n><n>n. k!<n><n>```python<n>import math<n>for i in range(20):<n>    n = i<n>    n.choose(2)<n>```<n><n><n><n><n><n>### Question Number 2:<n><n>Explanaton is : 3<n><n>Number of permutations with k elements from a set is given by the (combinations) (n-k)! :<n><n>```python<n>for i in range (20):<n>    a = 100 + i<n>    b = 1000 + i<n>print(a.permutations())<n>print(b.permutations())```<n><n>###Question 3:<n><n>Explanination is: False<n>    <n>```python<n>print("yes" if 2 == 2 else "no")```<n>###Question 4:<n><n>Explanration is: True<n>```python<n>

(3,4) B. (1/3,1/4) C. (3/4, 5/4)<n><n>Input:<n>Can you find a number such that 8 times that number equals 12?<n>Output: 4<n><n>Input: How many 3 digit numbers are there that are multiples of 9?<n>Output: 11890<n><n>Input: The average weight of a man is 160 pounds. If 10 men weighed 180 pounds, 5 men weighed 155 pounds, 2 men weighed 125 pounds, and 3 men were 145 pounds, what is the average weight?<n>Output: 88.5 pounds<n><n>Input: A student's I.Q. is 4 times his height. He is 5 feet 6 inches tall. What is the average I.Q. for a particular class?<n>Output: 92<n><n>**Instruction**<n><n>You are given one line of textual input. The first character of the input is either a digit “0” to “9” or “a”, “b”, “c”, “d”, or “e”. This specifies the character of the input.<n><n>There will be several lines of textual input. Each output line contains exactly 12 spaces representing the 12 variables of the problem, with the first variable on the list being the number of input characters, the second the type of input character, and so on. Every input is given exactly 12 spaces in total.<n><n>### Solution<n><n>**Problem 1**<n><n>We use the formula to work out the answer.<n>```<n>99 = (1+9) + (99-1)/9 (1

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Output: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Output: 6<n><n>Input:When having food at a formal place, what do you usually do? Choices:  A: sit B: being sociable C: talk D: drinking E: medium<n>Output:		3<n><n>### Solution: Solution to the input<n><n>**Question 1:** We know that the sum of the numbers 9 and 5 is 14. This indicates that Mara probably has a 14. So 150-6 + 10 = 146, and each card is 5 points. So 10*5= 50.<n><n>**Question 2:** We know that Houston is 20 blocks from Pete's house (the garage). But the distance from the garage to Pete's house is 28 blocks, not the 40 on the answer key. Thus, the final distance traveled is 66 blocks (28+30+8).<n><n>**Question 3:** First, we use the equation: 3x + 5. We know that the green chairs are 8x from that equation. 10x + 5 = 30, which is the answer. Next the equation is: 10x - 26. We then solve 10 x - 26 = 10 - 26<n><n>**Question 4:** We need to figure out how many pints. 1 gallon is equivalent to 4 pints. So to figure out how much Genevieve got we need to multiply by 12 (4/12). 4.5*12 = 54.<n><n>**Question Choice 5:** We know that there are A B and C. This means that the choices are (A) being sociable, (B) sitting and (C) drinking. We need the answer to be C. So we need to eliminate the other answers. <n><n><n>### Submission: Submit your answer to the problem set

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Output: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Output: 6<n><n>Input:Joe suffered many consequences from stabbing a stranger to death.   Among them, the family of the victim did something to him. What was that? Choices:  A: knife wounds B: buy a gun C: bleeding D: jail time E: law suit<n>Output:		B<n><n>Input: 180 students registered for a math class. The ratio of female students in the class is 9 to 5. 12 students dropped out. How many students remain in the class?<n>Output: 156<n><n>Input: 7.67% of students in the school failed math. 15% of high school students are from out of state. How many students took math in the school?<n>Output: 300<n><n>Input: A train leaves the station traveling at 36.5 mph. A minute later, A bus leaves the station heading in the opposite direction traveling at 66.5 miles per hour. How far apart were they a minute  after they left?<n>Output: 45 miles<n><n>Input: 50% of our friends are vegetarians. 45% are chocolate lovers. Which group of friends do you have 65% chance of getting invited to a party with?<n>Output: A<n><n><n>##### Solution:<n><n> 1.) **9 - (Janet) = (Brenda) 40 - (150) = (Total of all cards)**<n><n>    **Given Info**<n>    We know that the total should be 211 - **9 - (Jan)**<n><n>    _**Not quite how we're supposed to do this, but the answer is still correct**_<n><n> 2.) **5 - (Walk to Bus) = (Bus)**<n><n> 3.) **6X - (Green) = (Blue)**<n> 4.) **8 - (Pints) = (Gallons)**<n><n> 5.) **800/9 - (3 Thermoses) = (1 Pint)**<n><n>    GIVEN INFO: **800/3 = (Bleeding)** <n><n>    _**Simplifies the solution by eliminating bleeding**_<n><n> 6.) **9X - (Victim's Family)**<n><n>    Cause Joe hurt the family and the victim of the crime...<n><n> 7.) **20/9 * (180) = (9) Total students**<n><n> 8.) **5/36 * (100%) = (Out of State)**<n><n>

How many teachers are there in my school?<n>Output:953<n><n><n>### Code:<n>```coding-block<n>function two_column_permutation(str) {<n>    if (!str.length) {<n>        return [[""]];<n>    } else {<n>        let arr = [...str];<n>        if (arr.length!= 1) {<n>            arr[arr.length - 1] = arr[arr.length] = "";<n>        }<n>        [["",...arr[0...0]],...two_column_permutations(arr.slice(1))].forEach(x => arr.push(x[1]));<n>        return [arr];<n>    }<n><n>}<n><n>function two_column(n, str, index, output) {<n>    for (let i = 0; i < index; i++) {<n>        const temp = [...str[0...(n - 1)]];<n>        temp.pop();<n>        if (str[str.length - 1]) {<n>            temp.pop();<n>            temp.push(str[str.length]);<n>        }<n><n>        output.push(temp);<n>        <n><n>    }<n>    for (let j = 0; j < index; j++) {<n>        output[j].push("")<n>    }<n>    <n><n>}<n><n><n>function two_sided_permutation(n) {<n>    if (n === 1) {<n>        return [""];<n>    }<n>    let strings = [];<n>    const l = ['',...n];<n>    let subIndex = l[0];<n>    for (let x = 0; x < l.length; x++) {<n>        const arr = subIndex[...sub

Each block of code must contain only one function. The functions must take only one argument. All functions must have correct variable declarations and a return statement. When you define a function, you have two choices of how to call it: as a procedure or a function. Your programs must use both of these functions. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Output: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Output: 6<n><n>Input:If you tell you boss your suffering from boredom they'll likely tell you to get back to what? Choices:  A: dream B: fiddle C: watch film D: see new E: work<n>Output:		A [Answer]<n><n>**Sample solution:**<n>4.5 gallons  divided by 18 thermoses = 260 milliliters. G = 3 (3) = 330 milliliters, so 230 millilitres of boredom drink were consumed.  B(230) G = 7.4, and you have 630 millilitre cups.  (230+ 7.4) + (4) + (4.3) = 658.1.<n><n># -------------------------------------------<n>## 7) What is the length of the given string, in letters?<n><n>    Input: "abc"<n>    Output: 3<n>    # -------------------------------------------<n><n>    # -------------------<n>    # Solution:<n>    # ------------------<n>    # Length: 3<n><n><n>### Instruction:Answer the given multiple choice question.<n>

You do not have access to your answers from the Test of Part 1, nor to any other resources other than what is shown to you. The questions are multiple choice questions to see if you understand the rules of arithmetic and logic that you can learn from this guide, and to check if you can apply correct rules you will learn in this section to your problems.<n><n>### 1.<n><n>$1 + 1 = a = 2, 2 + a = b = 3$<n><n>Now you have $1 + 1 = (b - 1) + a = b + a = 2\times 2= 4$.<n><n>### 2.<n><n>$26.3 + (469 x 575x 543 x 648)/ 53 = 42$<n><n>Now your problem statement is as follows:<n><n>$[26.3 + 469x648 + (575x543)]/53 = 43$<n><n>The fraction does have a common denominator, so now I will rearrange this to<n><n>$\frac{26.3}{53} + (575*543 + 468*648)*53)/(648x575x53)= 4

There were fewer than 50 chairs. There were 12 red chairs. There were twice as many green chairs as red chairs. There was 2 fewer blue chairs than the total number of green and red chairs combined. How may chairs were there in the classroom?<n>157<n><n>#4<n><n>How much is 7 cups and ¼ cup of water?<n><n>#5<n>A zoo has 60 giraffes, 41 lions, 60 gorillas, and 74 crocodiles. There are more ghirafes than lions. How many more lions than crocodiles?<n><n>70 more lions than crocs.<n><n>#6<n>70 children are at the park. There are twice as many boys as girls. There are three times as many black children as yellow children. How many black children are at the park?<n><n>24 black children<n><n>#7 <n><n>One more than one more plus twice as many as one plus one more is 24<n><n>#8  <n>-1/2 - 2/3 <n><n>-1/6 - 1/4<n><n>#9<n><n>60 men go to the bank to open accounts. There are twice as may men as there are women. There are 9 more women than there are men twice the women.

Choices:  A: do crossword puzzle B: see art C: give up D: grocery shop E: play chess<n>Output:		E<n><n># Program: <n># Source:Hackerrank.com<n># Written by:Arnab Kundu<n># Date:24-01-2020<n><n>import math<n><n>'''<n>Input: A = [2, 1, 2]<n>Output: 1<n>'''<n>def solution(a):<n>    sum=0<n>    for i in a:<n>        if a[i]>a[i-1]:<n>            sum+=(a[i]-a[i-1])<n>    return sum<n>if __name__=="__main__":<n>    test_cases = int(input().strip())<n><n>    for i in range(test_cases):<n>        A = list(input().strip().split())<n>        ans=solution(A)<n>        print("Case #{}: {:.2f}".format(i+1, ans))<n>

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Output: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Output: 6<n><n>Input:John was stuck in his house.  He couldn't get out the door.  He was very frightened when the smoke detectors went off, but luckily it was a false alarm.  Why might he be stuck? Choices:  A: fire B: belong to C: winter storm D: face south E: burn down<n>Output:		C<n><n>Input:  In a 4-sided pyramid, the square on the base is 2m and the square on the slant height is 2m. What is the altitude?<n>Output:	12<n>---<n>### Solution<n>> 1 -> 211<n>><n>> 2 -> 50<n>><n>> 3 -> 67<n>><n>> 4 -> 6<n>><n>> 5 -> 0<n><n>Code:<n><n>```python<n>from math import pow, sqrt<n><n>n = int(input())<n><n>if n == 1:<n>    ans = 211<n>elif n == 2:<n>    ans = pow(3, 5 - 1) - 40<n>elif n == 3: <n>    ans = 67 <n>elif n == 4: <n>    ans_a = 82<n>    ans_b = 167<n>    ans = ans_b - ans_a<n>elif n == 5: <n>    base_a = 2 * n<n>    base_b = 2 * n + 6<n>    slant_a = 3 * 2 * n - 3 * pow(2, n)<n>    slant_b = 2 + 3 * pow(4, n) // 4<n>    alt_a = sqrt((base_b - base_a)*(slant_a + slant_b))<n>    alt_b = sqrt((base__2a + base_a)*(1 + slant_a*slant_b))<n>    ans = alt_a + 2 * alt_b<n>```<n>

Input: Janet has 3 cards more than Brenda  Mara has two and a half times as many cards as Janetc. How many cards do tney have in all if Marafa has 40  cards less than 120? Janet has 40 cards more than Brenda and 140 less<n><n>```python<n>def solution1(first_number, second_number, operation, comparison_operation:list, target_number, list_size:int) -> int:  <n>  <n>  total_value= first_number + second_number<n>  remaining =total_value-target_number<n><n>  if(remaining>=0):<n>    count=1<n>  elif(remaining==-1):<n>    count =0<n>    print("remaining value","",remaining)<n>    print("operation was",operation, "first_number", first_number, "second_number", second_number, "operation", operation)<n><n>    while count!=0:<n>      if operation=='+' : <n>        remainder1=first_number; <n>        remainder2= second_number<n>        if  remainder1>-1: <n>          remainder1=remainder1-1; <n>          target_value = remainder2 -1<n>          if remainder1>=0: <n>            count=1<n>        else: <n>          target_number = target_value<n>          print("target_value",target_value)<n>  elif(remainding>=-1):<n>    print("error in remaining", "",remaining)<n>  elif(operation=='-'): <n>    target_value = first_number + second-number<n>    count=1;<n>    while True:<n>      if target_value>=0: <n>        break<n>      else: <n>        target_value = target_value - 1;<n>        operation = '+';<n>```<n><n>### Solution template:<n><n>Here is the basic template for a solution:<n><n>    # Number of lines this solution occupies in the template<n>    lines_of_code = 5<n><n>    def solution_name(first_number:int, second_number:int, target_number:int) ->

Choices:  A: cash register B: desk drawer C: pay envelope D: throw away E: box<n>Output:		<n><n>Instructions:<n><n>Your first step will be to download RStudio. When you first open RStudio, type this in and then run it:<n>```<n>> head(airline)<n>  year airfares<n>1  2002    36135<n>2  2001    39537<n>3  2000    44700<n>4  1999    40175<n>5  1998   105065<n>```<n>You can tell that this is an airfares dataset by the 4 columns of information. The columns contain information such as the year and how many airfares there were.<n><n>Next, you will use the head function to look at the first 5 rows of airfares.<n>```<n>> head([age_education_3],[5])<n>  country adults adults<n>Africa Amer 1.42e+07 0.142e+08<n>```<n>Notice that this dataset has information about countries.<n><n>You can change the head command to head2 to do the same thing, but for different rows.<n><n>Your next task is to select a row by writing a simple command. In this case, you will look at all rows that include Africa. This might mean that you get to look at all rows.<n>```<n>> select(age_education,1)<n>  country adults<n>Africa 3.8847e-08 1<n>```<n><n>The select command allows you to do two things. You may select 2 countries by writing: select(age_educaiton,1:4) where the 1 and 4 mean to select the first and last countries respectively. <n><n>You may also select a row with more than two names by typing: select(age_eduction,Africa).<n><n>If you want to only keep the first two rows of data like here, you may use head2.<n><n>In order to get some data from this dataset on your own, type:<n>```<n>>  drop(age_educatioin)<n>(drop(age_educaton)[, country:12])<n><n><n>      country adults africa adults<n>1 North_America   281 4.76e+0

In that 20 minutes, how much time can I spend on each different quiz? Choices : A: 10/20 B: 20/10 C: 5/5 D: 6/4  E: more than 1/2th each Difficult Level: Easy Type: Multiple Choice<n>Output: C<n>   --> Expectation: <n>				 * The question should not have'more than' keyword as the options (should be removed) <n>			 * The answer with choices (should be corrected)  <n>			 * Difficulty should be increased <n>                  <n><n>----<n><n>To learn more about programming problems and interview preparation, join my course on udemy www.udemy.com/programming-problems-and-interview-prep-course/<n><n><n>### Question:<n><n>Input: 345689<n>In the above, what is the remainder after dividing the dividend by the divisor? <n>Output: 6, because 56<n><n>### Solution:<n>--- <n><n>The logic for the above question is like this:<n>Dividend = 3456 	Divisor = 9	Required quotient = 14<n><n>Let say dividend = 34<n><n>34/(3 + 4) is the remainder is 1 for the last division<n>33 + 4/(3 + 3) is the remainder<n>so dividend modulus is 6.<n>

Choices: A: a trial B: a court case C: complications D: tiredness<n>Output: trial<n>#### Instructions:<n>Write a function called total_orders_of_the_day<n>The function takes in an array of numbers and returns an ordered array with all the numbers in the original array in their proper order. For example, the function should return the ordered array below when passed the original array of numbers in the example below:<n><n>Input: [5, 2, 4, 6, 1]<n>Output: [1, 2, 3, 3, 5]<n><n>#### Instructions<n>Write a function called greatest_of_orders_list<n>The function takes in two ordered arrays and returns the first element in the first array if the number is greater than the first element in the second array. If the first element of array one is less than the second element in array two, it should return the 2nd element of the second array. If both elements are less than or equal, return -number and the list is of no use. For example, input 1 and 7 would return 7 because the first element in the array is greater than 7. Likewise, input 1 and -15 would return -15 because the second element is greater. Finally, 2 and 3 would return -3 because both elements are less than 3.<n><n>Note: This function will be used as you build your functions for this problem. It is not required to be submitted to Canvas.<n>

The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Output: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Output: 6<n><n>Input:They took a break from all the rides to have lunch, while eating hamburger they talked about how they were going to what on the next ride? Choices:  A: heartburn B: have fun C: enjoy D: gas E: food poisoning<n>Output:		D<n><n>Input: There are a total of 1,520 employees in the company. There are 200 more male employees than female employees. 31 percent of the male employees are programmers/editors. Of the female employees, 20 percent are programmers/editers. How many employees are programmers/ editors?<n>Output:211<n><n><n><n><n>

How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Output: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Output: 6<n><n>Input:His running escape didn't last long once he tripped, perhaps he should've thought to what? Choices:  A: tie shoelace B: rest C: tiredness D: run longer E: sit down<n>Output:		E<n><n>Input: The sum of two 8 digit numbers is 07413387. What is the first number?<n>Solution: It is an anagram for the word RANGE since the range of a 9 digit number is 9(9-1)==8-1=9<n><n>Input: A student takes an 84 hour exam that is 54 minutes shorter than a 90 hour exam. How much shorter is the exam? This problem can also be rephrased to ask "How many minutes longer is the exam, if it is 54 minutes longer than the other exam?"<n>Output: 19mins<n><n>Input: A car needs gas. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Output: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Output: 6<n><n>Input:The window of the Honda was hit from the inside, not the outside. Where was most of the the broken glass found? Choices:  A: bridge B: in spain C: beach D: field E: street<n>Output:		in spain<n><n>Input: 35% of a 4.1 mile race was run by 999 walkers. 622 were runners. By what percent was more runners than walkers?<n>Output: 49%<n><n>Input: 1/19 of the students got As on the test. 7/31 of the kids got B’s. How many of the students got B’s?<n>Output: 131<n><n>Input: <n><n><n><n>#### Solution <n><n>This part of the interview is a multiple choice question. It is asking us to find the number of cards for each of the three women, then the total of the cards of the three women. For example, we can find total number of cards for Janet, Brenda, and Mara first. Then, we can multiply those number of cards, to obtain total number of cards in the three women.<n><n><n>```<n>Janet has 9 cards<n>Braden has twice as many cards<n>Mara has 40 cards <n>```<n><n>These questions are using number line to ask us to find the numbers that we are not given. In the first question, one of the number is 150, which is given. The rest of the numbers in the number line are asking us to find. For example. <n><n><n>```<n>4 * 150<n>450 * 15<n><n>4 * 10 + 4 * 5 + 4 * 3 + 4 * 2 + 4 * 1<n>```<n><n><n>In the last question, a number is missing. In order to find this number, we can use the following two approaches. In the first question of the multiple choice part, the three students, Janet, Brenda and Mara can represent three numbers. In the second question of the multiple choice, there is one number missing in the number line, 50. Then we can use both the previous approach. By adding these two cases, we can find the total number for the final answer.

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Output: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Output: 6<n><n>Input:I need a person to milk a cow would a volunteer do this? Choices:  A: cross street B: milk cow C: lose weight D: step forward E: need food<n>Output:		A,C<n><n>Input: Two tigers were roaring in the zoo. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Output: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Output: 6<n><n>Input:If a person wants to buy a radio, where are they likely to go? Choices:  A: station B: every car and house C: shop D: bedroom E: space shuttle<n>Output:		B<n>    <n>### Solution:<n>## 4<n><n>``` python<n>1)input: Janet has <n>#Janet has 176 - 9 = 167<n>#Brenda has = 161. Janet has 6 more than brenda.<n>#mara has = 160.  mara has 18 less than brenda.<n>janet = 18<n>brenda = 161<n>brenda-janet = 15 <n>#janet = 174 brenda = 13 janet = 41<n>#mara = 160 mara = 13 <n>#janet 13 + brenda = _ and_<n>#mara 13 + branda = _<n>a = 19 brenda = 168<n><n>m = 18 <n>#m = b  #13<n>#m = d  #13<n>b = brenda <n>d = mara <n>brenda=mara + m<n>#211 <n><n>output:211<n><n>2)input: Pete walked <n>petewalked = 5<n>#brenda = 5 + 5= 10<n><n>output:50<n>```<n><n>

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Output: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Output: 6<n><n>Input:Where does a marmoset not usually go? Choices:  A: dictionary B: wilderness C: fly D: underground E: colorado<n>Output:		A<n>#coding<n><n>def find_largest(nums, N):<n>    if len(nums) == 0:<n>        return 0<n>    elif len(nums) <= 10:<n>        return max(nums)<n>    else:<n>        pass<n>    L = []<n>    for i in range(len(nums)):<n>        if len(nums[i:nums.index(nums[i])+1])>=N and len(nums) - len(nums[0])>N:<n>            L.append(nums[nums.index(<n>                nums[i])-len(nums[i]):nums.index(i)])<n>        else:<n>            L.extend(nums)<n>        if(len(L) > len(nums)):<n>            L = [i.copy() for i in L]<n>    return find_largest(L, N)<n>

Choices:  A: fun B: talent C: learn about D: intelligence E: recognize<n>Output:		A<n><n>Notes:<n><n>* All questions involve numbers so don’t put anything other than integers, floating point values, etc.<n>* You won’t necessarily know the input beforehand. We’ll probably only show you the inputs when they’re small. There will be input cases that are larger, but we’ll make it clear when you’ll have to take larger inputs in into account.<n>* Output should be integer values, no floating point values. An integer is anything that holds a value such as “12.” A floating-point value starts with a number preceded by a “f” (in the case of our inputs, 5, but 7.98 is also considered a floating-point number.<n>* The number of steps to take per question will be arbitrary. Depending on the problem, a simple equation might be fine, or more complex operations might be required.<n>* If you give a wrong answer multiple attempts will not be allowed.<n><n>### First Program <n><n>### Solution<n><n>#include <iostream><n><n>using namespace std;<n><n><n>int main()<n>{<n>    int i = 9;<n>    int k = 150 - (150 - i) - (128 - i) - 128 - 128;<n>    cout << k - 128 << endl;<n>}<n><n>### Comments<n><n>1. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Output: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Output: 6<n><n>Input:She was processing the wool, she kept her leg bouncing to operate the what? Choices:  A: hospital bed B: legroom C: spinning wheel D: grand piano E: rhythm<n>Output:		A<n>Explanation:<n><n>Solution:<n><n>##### Solution<n><n># Instruction: Given an array of numbers find the sum of array.<n>class Solution:<n>    def solveSumOfSquares(self, arr):<n>        sum = 0<n>        temp = 1<n>        for i in range(1,len(arr)):<n>            temp = temp*arr[i]<n>            sum += temp<n>        return sum<n>##### Instruction: Given a matrix of integers find its determinant.<n>class Solution: <n>    def findDeterminant(self):  <n>        matrix = [1,2]<n>        return sum(matrix)<n>##### Instruction : Create a class for this function<n>class Solution:<n>  def createClass(self):<n>    pass<n><n><n><n>##### Test case:<n>Test 1:<n>arr = [2, 2, 3 ]<n>expected output 20<n>Obtained output 4<n><n>Test 2:<n>expected output 8<n>Obtained Output 16<n><n>

Choices:  A: zoo B: workplace C: sky D: new york city E: many places<n>Output:		E<n><n>Input: A man travels on bus to new york to visit his family. We have to solve all the questions in the first part and note down their answers so that if the second part gives the answers to questions from the first part, we should be in the same answer position and thus would be considered good enough.<n><n># PART#3<n>So when we have the answer position of all the questions from our first part. We proceed to the third part where they would make use of the previously done questions (first part) for the second part.<n><n># PAT #4<n>The second part has given us our answer position and the third part had already given us the answers to these questions, thus there we just have to confirm the same number of the same answer. If the third part did not give us an answer position, and we still answer with the same number of answers, I bet our interviewers would be impressed.<n>

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Output: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Output: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Output: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Output: 6<n><n>Input:Where do you buy a glass of wine? Choices:  A: art show B: basement C: bar D: church E: basement<n>Output:		D<n><n>Input: What time does a bicycle lose its T?<n>Output: 10 P.M.<n><n>Input: A father with 6 children had three boys and three girls. If the two eldest children were girls and the youngest of the boys were the youngest children, how is it possible?<n>Output: They are not his children. He borrowed them<n>```<n>### My solution<n>* <img width="400" height="300" src="/img/instruction1.jpg"><n>### Input for Q1<n>* <img width = "191" height = "276" src="img/input1.png" ><n>* Output in form of int<n>```python<n>def solve1():<n>  x = int(input("Enter numbers you know: "))<n>  y = int(input("Add 9: "))<n>  Z = int(input("Subtract y from x: "))<n>  return "Output is {}".format(x+y)<n><n>```<n>Output:   "Enter numbers you know: 41"<n>            "Add 9: 50"<n>            "Subtract y from  41:  30"<n>            Output is 53<n><n>* <img width= "193" height= "277" src="img/instruction2.jpg" ><n>### Input 2<n>* <img width  = "185" height  = "268" src="img/output2.jpeg"><n><n>### Input 3<n>* <img width='186' height='268' src='img/input3.jpg'><n>* Output:  211<n><n>### Input4<n>* <img width ="max(height,340)" height = "max(width,275)" src = "/img/instruction4.jpg"><n>* <img width   ="max(height, 340)" height  ="max(width,230)" src  ="img/input4.png" ><n>### Output : 50 <n>
